instruction: Here's your instruction: Create a hopeful and encouraging social media post that highlights the importance of perseverance during challenging times, using a personal story or example as inspiration.
output: Sometimes, you see unrelated items and they message together.  I saw that the Community College of VT is celebrating its 52nd Commencement.  The same newsletter noted that the Hermitage might be auctioned off.  What a contrast.  That got me thinking again of Southern Vermont College, founded in 1926.  This will be its 93rd commencement if my math is right.  And, I hope it is not its last.  I, along with others, am committed to seeing if this remarkable college can celebrate its 100th Commencement!   I get the challenges.  I get the tightness of the timetable.  But, I still believe.  Yes.  So, don't bury SVC yet.  It's funeral may come but not if I can help it.  At least my group will go down fighting hard.  Very hard.  If you don't try and don't believe, I can assure you nothing survives.  So, best to try and believe.  The other pathways foreshadow doom.  And, for the record, doom and lack of transparency aren't my thing.  Success is -- and I mean success not in the monetary sense. I mean in helping people become their best selves.  That's part of the SVC mission -- enabling people to realize on their potential.  How any anyone who believes in the mission NOT fight?       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post discussing the importance of cultural competency in today's globalized world and share your personal experience on how learning another language has helped you build cultural awareness
output: Well, this is a post of a different nature. Many moons ago, an old friend Steve Leveen asked if I would do a podcast where he interviewed me for his site and project: America the Bilingual.  I did but promptly forgot about the initiative until he just completed a podcast called Buds of Bilingualism and there I am speaking Icelandic.  It brought back memories, reminding me of my own tradition where I give the introduction to my remarks in the language of the nation where I am speaking. I had recently been in the Yakama Nation and started my remarks at Heritage University in Yakama. So, you are interested in how to use foreign language to develop cultural competency, this podcast's for you. Link's below.  But, for me, the podcast also raises a deeply troubling question in American education. We seem to look down at our non- or beginning English speaking students. Because they do not speak our language, we assume them to be "lesser."  Yet, they speak more languages than most Americans -- they speak their native language plus at least some English. So why do we denigrate others who speak a non-English language well and are learning English rapidly? Can you explain that?  Here's the podcast link:       …see more

instruction: The instruction should reflect the themes present in the original post.Instruction: Create a LinkedIn post discussing the importance of processing trauma in place and fostering community during times of crisis. Use
output: I want to share a concept in my new book on trauma that is  counter-intuitive.   When disasters strike like shootings at schools/colleges, we often go on lockdown and then release kids to families or older students to their dorms or homes.  We even shut down institutions. If the end of a school year is upon us, we wrap things up and folks depart. I think more attention needs to be paid to what I call “processing in place.”  Instead of separating people, we need to focus on and foster community.  Instead of going away, we need to go back and share with those who were there.   Ponder the experience of soldiers when they get stateside and lose their buddies.  Is that why vet suicides occur at VA hospital sites—the soldier is with others like them in some sense?   In the case  of UNC-Charlotte, the end of the semester is not trauma’s friend.  Perhaps the university will extend the semester, allowing students, faculty and staff to process in place — if they want that. How we process in place isn’t a simple idea and if space is tainted, that’s problematic.  More on those points later.  But you can’t process in place if you aren’t in place — physically or perhaps virtually.   Ponder the power of processing in place with me.       …see more

instruction: Can you help me craft a LinkedIn post that reflects the same sense of hope and determination as the one shared by the author? I want to encourage my followers to believe that
output: Please don't forget that some of us are still trying to save the college as a going concern. And phoenixes do rise from the ashes. I appreciate that most folks around this table pictured here seem to think SVC is dead and gone and are thinking of post-death solutions. I for one have not put the final nail in the SVC coffin. Try to remember that that option still is there --- and some of us are not giving up. Be assured we will fight til our last option is closed. And, these ideas are not Quixotic or fraudulent as some have alleged. Please be serious -- Fraud is not what's being proposed. Innovative bold creative long range ideas for a new SVC are well in the works, staying true to its mission, not trying to be "elite," preserving nursing and rad tech, refinancing with the bank, contributing to the community, athletics, graduates from near and far and staying alive. Plans will be forthcoming we hope -- including ones that enable faculty and staff to be paid and even a summer program. Don't kill the goose before its time. No promises but there is a promise to keep trying. So, folks, no funerals. No obituaries. Drs don't give up easily on their patients. We won't either.       …see more

instruction: Instructions: Create a LinkedIn post that discusses a recent social justice issue and proposes a solution that involves redistribution of resources. Use language that is persuasive and inspiring
output: Folks, yesterday saw guilty pleas of a dozen or so wealthy parents and coaches for bribery, illegal money transfers across state lines, and tax fraud among other charges.  Felicity issued an apology, seemingly sincere.  Here's an idea I want to refloat:    When we get to the punishment phase, I want to reiterate the idea of a cy pres award. Elite colleges were harmed. True. But the whole incident shines a spotlight in inequality in education and across America. And, ironically, the bribes ostensibly went to help low income kids. Yup, that's the tax fraud part. So have those pleading guilty do just that: donate to a cy pres fund that benefits low income kids and the non-elite small colleges that serve them. Redistribute the cy pres to colleges with more than 40% Pell eligible students and/or 50% first gen students and under 1200 students and endowments under $10 million. Then use the funds for scholarships and institution sustainability. The cy pres agreement would be part of a court ordered settlement and the distribution could be decided by a cy pres committee or designated court appointed official. Make lemonade out of lemons. Force these parents to do what they actually said: give to help low income students. Do good from bad.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a similar theme of effort and alternatives to certificates, discussing the importance of providing real degrees and support to students at small non-elite colleges
output: So, first, silence for a few days does not mean I am not pursuing approaches to try to save SVC (and other small colleges that serve students — nursing, Rad tech, cj, social services, business.) The articles today in Chronicle of Higher Ed are telling about the price students pay when their college closes.  Can we do better?  Can we help these institutions?  Surely we can try.  Without trying, we get nowhere.  So I’m trying on several fronts - legal and fundraising and gov.    On a somewhat related topic, watch for a new post on colleges issuing certificates of failure to show students it is ok to fail.  Not sure what psychologist or professor dreamt up this idea and I appreciate that learning involves risk taking.   But, certificates of failure?  To hang on a wall?  To acknowledge competition?  To make bad grades acceptable?  I see vastly different ways to help students other than  issuing failure certificates.    Piece to appear shortly.  At small non-elite colleges, can you imagine certificates of failure?  Wait til you see them — look like degrees except for failure.  Yipes.  Another Yipes.  I believe in real degrees and real support.  Not diplomas of failure.       …see more

instruction: Come up with a funny but practical suggestion for news anchors to improve their weather reporting. Your tip should involve a simple yet effective change that helps them accurately describe the current weather
output: I have an idea. You know how the Aspen Institute has its five best ideas for the day? Well, I have one. Weather reporters should have a window in their office/studio. That way, they can actually see the weather they are reporting. This morning, a station said there was no rain. Really? Stick your head out the window or walk the dog. It was and still is raining. Seems to me this is an easy fix. Ask weather folks to look out the window. Then they might be reporting the actual weather. Just saying.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the importance of preserving small colleges, highlighting the role they play in serving communities and students who may not have access to elite institutions. Share personal
output: I have often thought rich colleges could partner with less wealthy colleges — sort of academic adoption.  When endowment size was an issue that threatened their continuance, I thought this was an idea: invest in a neighboring small colleges and help them thrive and now survive.  No takers.  Williams wasn’t interested when I asked and their president then (not Morty Shapiro) showed overt disdain.  I actually chatted with famous Yale endowment advisor (Swensen) and he saw merit. That said, the rich get richer.  And small colleges that serve communities and students who are not going to elite colleges for any number of reasons, get poorer.  Sure, some small colleges are not being innovative and creative.  I still believe SVC can be saved and I continue to pursue different avenues regardless of naysayers.  Giving up isn’t in my vocabulary.  SVC didn’t train nurses and Rad techs to give up on patients.  We didn’t give up on students who struggled.  So, why give up on SVC?  Bravo to the author!       …see more

instruction: The instruction could involve generating content on a similar topic or writing in a similar style. For example, Write a LinkedIn post about the importance of teamwork in achieving success, using relatable an
output: So I am sitting in a crowd of strangers,  not in NE.  Someone asks what I do.  I say, which is partly accurate as of this moment in time, I am trying to save a small non elite college.  I explain that despite the current protestations and accusations, I left it after 8 years in good shape and fully capable survival.  In the 4 plus years since I left, it tanked.  And it fell precipitously in the last 2 years. Someone said, that’s impossible.  Colleges don’t crater and suddenly announce they’re shutting.  Something’s wrong. Something happened in the recent past. I said, well, maybe but more likely something didn’t happen: fundraising, grant raising, admissions, athletic recruiting, poor acquisitions.  But, I explained I hadn’t seen financials or data or what was filed with accreditors.  The group looked at me quizzically and I just looked at them and said, beats me.  My job now is to try to save it.  Anyone here have 3 million and want a college named for them? A few laughs and no immediate takers but one fellow said:  I bet there is someone like that.  I said:  I know.  I am looking for him or her right now. Funny how life is, isn’t it? What if one of those people was that one? Folks:  if you don’t try to save a place it will never be saved.       …see more

instruction: Write a post about perseverance that mentions a historical figure as a symbol of determination.Instruction: Create a LinkedIn post with a focus on the theme of
output: People laughed at Don Quijote.  People have laughed at my effort to try to save Southern Vermont College, including some who should be embarrassed.   Here’s my view:  we message when we try hard tasks.  We don’t cave (think caves at SVC).  We need to message.  Sure, it is wise to have an orderly closure.   It is never wise to make fun of innovators.  It is never wise to assume one has a lock on the answers.  Goodness:  leaders need to show humility and hope and faith and belief in the power of the possible.  Don Quijote became and is a classic that inspires.  Many of us are Quixotic.  I will never ever apologize for that.     The title of my new children’s book (released April 10th at Northshire bookstore in VT) messages that again and again and again.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post, using a tone of encouragement and hope, about how persistence and innovation can help prevent failures in small businesses during tough times.
output: A quick post.   Saving a small college (saving anyone or anything) isn’t easy.  And it doesn’t always work.   But I am not done trying to save Southern Vermont College.  The final nail is not in the coffin.  And I want a replicable and scalable model given all the small non-elite colleges failing. Yes, the Board withdrew the appeal and everyone in power is focused on closing.  A “good” closure is important but it is not a victory. I still have ideas percolating.  I am not scared to think boldly and innovatively  and I understand risk.  Doug Flutie knows about Hail Marys.  Many have seen last second three pointers —  and guess what, sometimes they win the game. You don’t and can’t count on Hail Marys or three pointers when the clock is at 00.01.  So plan accordingly but don’t give up.  There is no reason NOT to keep trying. Isn’t that what we teach and preach?  Don’t give up.  Open new doors. Try.  Try again, even in the face of naysayers. At least if you try, you will be able to sleep at night in the coming months and years.   There is value in peace. # In the meanwhile, show support for saving a college by giving and messaging: https://lnkd.in/epz9TZv.       …see more

instruction: The instruction could ask for a quote or story from someone who's gone through a difficult time and persevered, or it could request tips on how to stay motivated during tough times. Your
output: So, April the Giraffe is giving birth and thousands are fascinated as nature takes its course and nature’s beauty abounds.  People by the thousands are glued to the giraffe cam.  And there’s running comments on a feed.  April has the patience and calm of a saint; her partner Oliver is pacing.  In a world of bad news, this is of value and absent a medical disaster, a new giraffe will grace our presence soon. As this is happening, I am working to birth (save) a college — Southern Vermont College.   Unlike April, I am not patient and the birthing is filled with hurdles and mistruths that can’t be cured by the peppermint and pickles April is getting.   But, I’m not giving up. And I won’t  go down w/o a fight despite all the naysayers.  Don’t get me started on the misstatements. Makes my blood boil.   And folks are watching to see if this college can be birthed/saved.  They are watching closely as they should.  There’s no cam to capture the efforts but they exist for sure and for real. Here’s a thought. If April gives birth today, that’s a sign perhaps of another birth today.  Both the new giraffe and college will need nurturing and stability and care.  Both can get that. Here’s hoping today is a good birth day amidst the frenzied and frightening stories about college admissions.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the unfairness and inequity in the accreditation process for non-profit colleges, highlighting specific examples and calling for action to address these
output: Something is drastically wrong with college accreditation, both in terms of who is getting and maintaining accreditation and who is losing it.  Bennett College was cited for lack of resources; it had an opportunity to raise $$ before the appeal.  The goal was $5 million but over $9 million was raised. The accreditor was unimpressed apparently and said: this was not enough. It’s like moving the standard higher when you hit the mark.  How does that work?  Now consider the for profit college accreditor which was removed by the prior administration  for failure to identify quality educational gaps in the institutions it oversaw and playing favorites.  Under the current administration, this decision is being reversed.  Does anyone see the irony, the inequity, the unfairness to small private non profits? Since when can we reverse decisions or move the goal posts with such ease?  I’m worried about small college accreditation.  You should too.  I am worried about for profit accreditation.  You should too.  Does the fact that Bennett is an HBCU cut against them?   Just asking if big corporate educators can crush small historic places that serve students not shareholders. Someone  is up a creek with no paddle — because it was taken while someone else was given a paddle.  Hum.       …see more

instruction: Write a post on LinkedIn about the importance of taking responsibility as a leader during times of crisis, using examples from recent events and sharing your personal insights on the matter.
output: Here's a lesson for leadership in a time of crisis:  When things go wrong, a leader needs to own the wrongs that have occurred.  It's easy to cast blame on others who held power in the past. But anyone holding a leadership position for more than a year or two has to take responsibility for current messes/mistakes. And, new leaders, this is hard and I know from experience and my own errors: you can only blame your predecessor and institutional bad acts for so long.  Once one gets the lay of the land, a leader owns the institution's past. Ownership is key to trustworthiness, the ability to live with oneself and to take real action.  Blame gets you nowhere. Why do I raise this now? With all the institutions struggling with one crisis or another, particularly in education, we can see the value of being forthright.  Stand up and own what went/is wrong. And, then take the steps needed to remedy the situation. Think Georgetown owning its slave past. Remarkable. Think Penn State not owning its silence. Troubling.  And, by the by, PR folks would agree: It's best for institutions moving forward if their leaders step forward.  Remember the President of Columbia who climbed out his office window to avoid student protesters? As they say in the law, res ipsa.  #presidency   #leadership   #crises       …see more

instruction: Instructions: Write a LinkedIn post that explores the importance of actively listening for truth and integrity during a hearing process. Your post should emphasize the significance of leaving personal beliefs aside
output: Assuming Dr. Ford testifies, I want to know how we can get people on the Judiciary Committee and in the Senate truly to listen. Could we put our R/D affiliation in a drawer and just listen and hear?  If the point of a hearing is to hear, then prejudging and announcing one's vote ahead of time or that Judge Kavanaugh will be appointed misses the point of a hearing. And why plow ahead?  We plow fields not people. I get the rush but do we do justice by rushing to find truth? One more thought:  Youthful indiscretion is not rare. What is bad here is: failure to own one's past; failure to apologize; lying. The Justices decide about real people; truth matters.  Truly matters.  So does integrity.  So does honesty.  Judge Kavanaugh is not being criminally charged (too late); but he bears burden of persuasion.  This isn't about innocent until proven guilty in a criminal trial. There is no trial. There is a hearing on fitness and integrity. Worth distinguishing and remembering.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post in the style of the author of the previous post, but with a focus on how small liberal arts colleges contribute to society.
output: A recent article in the Boston Globe described the struggles of small colleges and their likely collapse in the not too distant future. Sure, some will close but I have a different take. Here's a part of my response: As the former president for 8 plus yrs of one of the colleges referenced, I want to share a more optimistic take on small colleges, including the one I led with a remarkable team over the years.  I want to begin with three questions: (1) Whom do these colleges serve? (2) Are their graduates better for having attended and graduated (and even those who stopped out, are they better for the experience)? and (3) If not small colleges, where?    Ponder these questions/answers. Small colleges, non-elite small colleges, help many first generation, Pell eligible students find their way.  That's powerful in and of itself.  Small colleges have faculty who actually teach, and teaching and pedagogy matter to them.  Small colleges produce people who help make the world go round: police officers, nurses, community based workers, social workers, teachers, small entrepreneurs, radiology techs, healthcare advocates, coaches.  Returning to the article: You bet there is a place for small colleges.  I'd put money on it.  I believe.  My question is really: why don't you?       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that highlights the importance of perseverance in achieving success, using examples of individuals who overcame adversity through hard work and determination. The post
output: It makes me sick.  First someone gleefully kills a rare giraffe. Then we imprison (detain) kids and/or families. Then a golfer loses his clubs and refuses to play. He quits.  How many of us have lost things (or people) and had to plow ahead.  Win or lose. How can a golfer simply step it up -- borrow clubs, learn about his game from the bottom up, show kids effort, try and try again.  What a pathetic role model when we need one.  I get winning. I get getting a spot. But gee, life dealt you a bad hand and lost your luggage. Don't wimp out for goodness sake.  Your character could have been an exemplar. Now you look like a spoiled sport.  Give me a break. You quit?  I get specialty clubs and sponsorships. I get import of getting a spot.  But, many real people lose things and manage -- with grace and humor and effort.  McDowell, you paint yourself as a poor sport and a poor exemplar for your sport.  Really.  For real. Sad.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that elaborates on the importance of promoting accountability culture and change in preventing sexual harassment and abuse in educational institutions, providing concrete examples and actionable
output: So, an article appeared in Inside Higher Ed on why leaders are failing to stop sexual harassers/abuse/rape on their campuses.  Here was/is my answer: I think there are many reasons. 1st, try campus culture, an issue that runs wide and deep. So do traditions that encourage bad behavior. Look at Prep Schools as exemplars. 2nd, the "hands-off" leaders have real trouble; it's good to delegate but....And, there needs to be a culture of transparency and an overt culture where bad news can and must be shared, not buried. 3rd, there are rose colored glasses as in: this too will pass. Nope. It won't. 4th, much of the training is poor, and people resent needing training suggesting they know all the issues. Reform the training. Bring in outsiders to do it and make it worth the faculty, staff, coaches and administrators' time. Poor training leads to poor outcomes. And resentment about waste of time. 5th, how we handle crises when they occur on campuses is weak and needs reformation. We make things worse, not better, because we aren't experts. Bring them in. 6th, to return to my favorite topic: Ask this. If there were co-presidents, could all this happen as it did on all these campuses? Speculating yes. But, pretty confidently, I can say that co-presidencies would curb this.       …see more

instruction: User Instruction: Write a post on social media, with a minimum of 100 words, that highlights the selfless nature of motherhood, especially in times of crisis,
output: I just read this absolutely beautiful, honest and heart warming and heart wrenching piece written by the amazing Carrie Froese. It's titled the Magnitude of Motherhood.  Here's a link ( https://lnkd.in/d2SutnN ). Here's my response: What an absolutely beautiful piece. Heartwarming, heart wrenching and honest to its core.  I used to worry about my son dying -- for no particular reason. I just worried because life was and is filled with danger.  And, I could not imagine much worse fate than losing a child, except perhaps a child losing a parent when the child is young.  Now, my relationship with my adult son is strained for many reasons, some valid and others not.  But, as Mother's Day approaches I know this: there really is no love like a mother's for her child (or children).  And, one hopes that as a parent, one gives one's child both roots and wings as the saying goes.  And, one more thought on Mother's Day, for the children who don't have mothers or have mothers who don't care sufficiently or are psychologically absent:  don't despair. There may be no biological substitute but there are many of us more than willing to be "parents" or "mentors" or surrogate mothers if, as and when needed.  That's worth remembering too.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about a current event where truth has emerged despite initial beliefs being based on fiction. Use a similar style to the given post and incorporate relevant hashtags related
output: So, with the Cosby verdict, truth has finally emerged. I have been wondering if part of the problem is that many people saw Cosby as Dr. Huxtable, an example of conflating truth and fiction.  Ironically, both fellows dispensed meds -- only one was a doctor and not a real one at that.   We often confuse truth and fiction.  I think this is something as to which we can all fall prey --- not rape, goodness knows.  I mean we can mistake truth and fiction. We want to believe fictions -- they are often easier than truths.  We even enhance fiction sadly.  Just look at the Michigan State debacle.  Truth was buried.  We don't want heroes or doctors or presidents for that matter to fall -- so we psychologically distort truth.  Human flaw.  And now, the victims can see that truth does eventually show its face. Brava for their strength over all these years.  Fiction just got its comeuppance. #psychology #fiction #victims #truth       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post on the topic of school safety and gun violence, emphasizing the importance of addressing mental health issues as a preventative measure. Incorporate statistics
output: How many young people need to be killed or injured in America's schools before we address this situation, including the access to weapons by those who seem to misuse them?  I get the 2nd Amendment.  Can't we restrict ammunition amounts sold?  Can't we look at other nations? And the aftermath for students, teachers and families is hard -- filled with memories that are etched. If schools and churches (and other religious venues) aren't safe, where is it safe? And, for the record, making schools armed camps is not good for anyone -- who can learn in an environment that looks and feels like a prison.  And, without security, there is fear too.   Were I guessing, we need many more counselors -- mental health counselors for troubled students and surviving students, teachers, parents and administrators. We must do better.  We have to do better.  As educators, we must take a collective stand. How sad, too, that it is Valentine's Day -- ruined for those there forever.       …see more

instruction: For instance, Write a social media post discussing your experience with cultural differences and sensitivity during your travels abroad.
output: So, after the fortune cookie message (glad many of you read about it), I am now starting Day 5. So far, I've had many realizations, some obvious; others less so. Here's a wee sampling: 1.  Nations may speak the same language (in this case English) but there remain remarkable cultural differences notwithstanding. And some terms are different too: Q-tips are cotton buds is a fun example.  Take Sunday. It is really a day of rest. Many stores and restaurants were closed on and off campus. A day of reflection. I see that cultural sensitivity is needed every minute.  2.  I am apparently hyper-sensitive to being an American given our politics and President. Case in point. I misplaced my hair brush in the move (small but impt. item). I decided a beauty salon was a good place to go to buy a replacement and found one a short car ride from campus.  When they rang up the charges, the brush was over $27 US. Trust me, it was not a fancy brush. I suggested something was wrong with the price and while they were re-assessing the price for me agreeing that it seemed high, I added: "I may be an American but I am not stupid." Really, I said that. Yipes. More as the stay progresses.  I am already seeing that the academic literature read across nations differs vastly.       …see more

instruction: User: Can you generate a social media post in the style of the given text that emphasizes the importance of empathy and support in education and highlights the idea that success shouldn't
output: I just saw a quote by Annette Breaux that beautifully states what all teachers, professors and student life staff know or can benefit from knowing: "Remember, everyone in the classroom has a story that leads to misbehavior or defiance. 9 times out of 10, the story behind the behavior won't make you angry.  It will break your heart."   I'd change the word "classroom" to the word "campus"  or "school" --- and that expands the quote meaningfully and importantly.  I was recently on a panel where I suggested that we offer support to new minority faculty.  Another panelist said: why is that needed?  They can do it on their own.  I said: not everyone can or should be forced to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps.  What is wrong with helping others, even without their asking?  Let's be clear and candid: We all need help in one way or another. And, many of the rules of the game of the academy are not so clear and are not spelled out as another panelist pointed out so aptly.   And, if we can enable success, does it really matter as educators how we do it?  As long as success is there (real success), is there some reason we think those who don't ask for or get help are better?  Moral superiority for being able to work alone?  Please.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post highlighting practical strategies that schools and colleges can implement to enhance their approach to handling trauma experienced by students. Your content should include examples of concrete measures that
output: Watch for forthcoming piece with strategies for improving how schools and colleges handle trauma that students experience.  Concrete suggestions are provided. Key here is that traumatic experiences are an equal opportunity offender -- sadly.  While small t trauma is more prevalent in low income families, higher income households can have toxic stress, abuse and trauma too.  And Big T trauma such as that caused by person-made and nature-made disasters is an equal opportunity destroyer. My dad passed away in 2008 and my mom recently remarked that she had not danced at night since then and missed my dad and dancing. She is now 89.  So, I recruited my partner and he agreed to dance with my mom this week-end --- rug rolled up, drink in background and old fashioned music. Tradition revived for a night. output: Here's a suggestion. This July 4th and every July 4th, read the Declaration of Independence to your children. For the many years our now adult son lived at home, I read this document to him --- from start to finish -- on July 4th. (We read the I Have A Dream speech too on Martin Luther King Day).  I hope and think it helped him become the person that he is -- filled with a desire to help those in need and preserve what is valuable in and to our nation.   Create a new tradition then in your own family  -- whether you are a new parent or a parent of older children: Read one of our nation's founding documents and be proud of the message it sends. instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the dangers of exaggerating in job recommendations and share some examples of how this can hurt both the person receiving the recommendation and their future employer
output: Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace.       …see more

instruction: Can you generate a post for my social media that highlights the experiences of teachers working abroad, particularly in China? Maybe include some examples of innovative teaching methods they have implemented?
output: What is it like for a South Los Angeles native to be living in Florence, Italy, but teaching students at New York University Shanghai? A profound and extraordinary experience. I've got to share some photos of the fieldwork that students in Shanghai are carrying out. Perhaps educators here can use this assignment as a project because many of us are struggling to convert in-class work to the virtual. These are 1st year students. Their job was to do some fieldwork at a teahouse in the city. Blew me away.  Their commitment to the class makes me wonder how wonderful we would be in the US, if we gave more resources to schools across the board, more respect to teachers and more honor to students. Now we're facing unimaginable gaps. US folk, we are behind the curve ball, the corner pocket, the corn field and the corner sto'. Teachers, please be safe, sane and as productive as you can be during this time.  #teachers   #china   #internationalteacher   #educators   #collegeteaching   #pandemicteaching   #schools       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post in your own words about a personal experience with workplace hair discrimination that highlights the emotional impact and possible solutions to the issue.
output: Years ago I worked in an office in the summer for LA Parks & Rec before the swimming pools opened where I was a managing lifeguard. One day, I came into the office with cornrows. The secretary told me that she was embarrassed by my hairstyle and that, that wasn't ladylike. So, she sent me home. When I went home, I told my mother. Mom told me to go right back to that job with my natural hair and tell her to call her if she has a problem with her daughter's hair. That woman never spoke to me again. Hah! Unfortunately, this woman was vocal, many people silently discriminate in the work place against hair outside of the mainstream and especially if its a coily mane like mine. Employment, hair & politics. For a person with coils who once had locks and now rocks cornrows and headwraps, hair in the office space can get really ugly. Ark Republic's resident cartoonist, Matthew Gamble's six-strip comic "The Gambling Man" explores what I call meeting at the Coif Roads. https://lnkd.in/ePJCvkR       …see more

instruction: Can you help me write a social media post about talent acquisition that emphasizes the importance of demand generation over traditional lead generation tactics?
output: ‘Talent Marketing’ I didn’t make that up. It ain’t ‘Marketing’. It’s not exactly ‘employer branding’. When talents get 7-10 job offers every single week.  When companies struggle with paying candidates what FB, Amazon, Microsoft and Google can easily afford. In this reality, you need more than just actively reaching out to candidates. instruction: Create a LinkedIn post that emphasizes the importance of strong interview skills over any type of recommendation, be it formal or informal, and suggest strategies for improving one's
output: You ALL have unofficial recommendations We in HR do that all the time.  We get a candidate’s CV and you find out he/she was working with a friend of yours. Why not call that friend to get an unbiased opinion? As a sourcer, you have every right to use any (legal and legitimate) channel to gather information about a candidate. But how much do you professionally trust a friend?  How close was this friend to your candidate?   What do you do if the process is discret? There’s no wrong or right answer.  I treat recommendations like perfume - I enjoy their smell, but I’ll never drink them. The interview process is 5X more important than any recommendation, official or unofficial.  Yes, you should get yourself a good set of people who will gladly recommend you. But if you don’t heavily invest in your interview skills, the best recommendations in the world won’t help you.  #people   #hr   #career   #interviews       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post on LinkedIn, using the same theme of 'ghosting' and providing tips on how to avoid this practice in recruitment processes.
output: Ghosting has to stop.  A company gets in touch with you, inquires about your availability, and then - poof. Vanishes. You go to a job interview, you feel OK/good about the process, they tell you they’ll be in touch. And then… crickets.  It’s not only companies. Candidates do that all the time. Answering and then ignoring, scheduling a job interview and not showing up, not returning any calls.  Ghosting usually saves you 1-2 minutes of inconvenience. But it brands you as a douche forever.  No one likes uncertainty. Whatever you are - a candidate, a recruiter or a sourcer - treat people like you want to be treated. Be responsible. Learn to say ‘sorry, but no’. Stop ghosting. #ghosting   #career   #hr   #people       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post promoting networking on LinkedIn and sharing insights related to HR, hiring, and career development.
output: Do you accept every LinkedIn connection request?  You should.  When you publish any type of content, you WANT more people to see it. You WANT to increase your exposure.  Yeah, you might get spammed after accepting requests. it happens.  That shouldn’t stop you.  It also shouldn’t stop you from searching for like-minded individuals to actively connect to. It will benefit you in the long run. LinkedIn isn’t Facebook. Your connections don’t have to be your personal friends. They can just share some of your interests, work at the same company, or field.  When you reach over 10K friends, you can start worrying about the type of people you accept as connections.  Until then, unless the profile looks like a bot, you should accept all connection requests.  #hr   #hiring   #career   #linkedin       …see more

instruction: Can you summarize the roles of various HR professionals mentioned in the LinkedIn post and explain how they differ from each other? Create a similar post with a focus on the role
output: If you're interviewing for a job or just looking for a job - know whom you’re talking to. It matters. Big time.  Different positions, different responsibilities, different impact: Talent sourcer - creates a recruitment pipeline, from job posting to personal headhunting. Similar to scouting in sports. Talent Ops - enables the talent organization to work more effectively. In charge of scheduling and the interview process. Talent Acquisition Specialist - manages the entire hiring process, from screening to contract.  Talent Marketing Specialist- develops the company's Employer Branding and Recruitment Marketing strategies. In charge of evolving recruitment, so the company can attract top talent. HRBP - Responsible for you from the moment your onboarding process ends. HR analytics - collects and analyzes HR data, and applies it to make recommendations related to recruitment, retention, and legal compliance. In smaller companies, one person can cover a few of these positions. But these are DIFFERENT positions.  HR is NOT recruitment. And recruitment is NOT HR. it’s complicated :-)  #hr   #hiring   #career       …see more

instruction: User: Hey there! Can you help me write a LinkedIn post similar to the one I shared earlier, but instead focused on networking strategies during job hunting? And could you add some tips
output: Job hunt CANNOT be based only on feelings. Get data to back up your efforts: ☝🏼Organize it! Prepare an Excel/Monday/Huntr dedicated to your job search ☝🏼Document every company you applied for with the application date and position details. ☝🏼Document every rejection or process ☝🏼Track the source you applied through  Maybe when you apply to Team Lead roles you get rejected but for senior positions, you get to an interview? Maybe when you apply through friends you get to phone interview more easily?  Job search IS a job. And just like most high-tech jobs, data is crucial.  Don’t ignore your feelings. Of course not. Intuition goes a long way. But your gut instincts can mislead you, and intuition may fail you. It happens. Data’s job is to make sure you get it right. Any other questions one should ask himself when measuring their job search? Share them in the comments! #hr   #jobsearch   #people   #career       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post showcasing how the role of a project manager relates to that of a scrum master, and highlighting the unique qualities of both roles while
output: HR isn’t like all the other functions in a company.  It’s so different from all the business-focus positions - product, marketing, sales, R&D. It has its own unique qualities. My role, for example, as an sourcer is very similar to an SDR:  	Linkedin is one of our main tools 	Reaching out to prospects is daily routine 	We do cold calls  	We try to create the perfect pitch 	We use templates, but personalisation is the key 	Small wins are big wins for us, one prospect at a time. 	We’re Competitive  We even share the same memes! instruction: User: Hey, AI, I want you to generate a LinkedIn post that provides tips for using social media platforms like LinkedIn and Twitter to find new job opportunities, just like the
output: How to use your friends as personal recruiters when you look for new opportunities? One of the best tips I have for job seekers is to use friends and professional networks but, how to do it effectively? 1. Lookup for all of your 1st connections on LinkedIn, then organize them by- people that know you personally and can validate your work[from school, past companies, etc]  2.  Reach out to every one of these connections with a summary about yourself, what you are looking for, and ask them kindly to apply on your behalf to their companies. 3.  When they agree [Yay!], ask them to add a few words about your work together and to send it directly to the hiring manager. This has a lot of weight on the CV screening decision.  4.  When hiring managers have valid information about you from a friend they trust it and increases your chances to get hired. 5.  After passing the CV screening use your friend as your source of information about the company! Ask them about the culture, challenges, and projects, and prepare yourself for the phone screening! Just applying isn't enough these days, the game has changed and you need to do the best. #hr   #jobhuting   #linkedin   #recruitment       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that discusses the importance of understanding workplace politics during remote onboarding processes.
output: The real story about on-boarding from home🏡 It's a difficult thing to on-board in a new place, getting to know your teammates, managers, the company culture, unwritten rules, and more. And now, we need to do all of that online- boom!💥 Yes, it's hard and the main thing everyone is focused on is the relationships and I understand.  Relationships are the baseline for everything and yet we tend to forget a very important thing- Workplace politics!🔵🔴 Its difficult to understand from zoom meetings and this is our job as teammates to explain to the new people on our team. ✔️The history of the team (don't disrespect, this is important!), projects, fliers and wins.  ✔️Relationships with other teams ✔️Social relationships between teammates  This is crucial information, and when you on-board via zoom you don't always manage to get it. Did I miss something? comment and let me know what do you think. #HR   #workpkacepolitics   #onboarding   #people       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that highlights the importance of prioritizing the candidate experience during the hiring process and offers practical tips for reducing uncertainty for job seekers.
output: Everyone is focused on the employee experience. What about the candidate experience? This was always tough. This new reality makes it even tougher. A lot of companies are trying to gain an advantage with ‘goods’ - mainly sending gifts to a candidates’ home. That’s not a bad effort. That makes candidates feel special. It will never replace the human touch. Candidates deal with uncertainty. Waiting for answers, getting feedback - these are their core challenges. It’s great to get a fruit basket or a bottle of wine, but it can’t come at the expense of being there - providing interview feedback, being available for questions, giving answers - reducing uncertainty. All employees were once candidates. Never forget that. #hr   #interview   #career   #people   #recruiting       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post about job interviews that emphasizes the importance of understanding a company's culture beyond just the compensation offered. Use hashtags like #never, #
output: Honestly -  Can you get a ‘feel’ of a new workplace from your home? Can you get a taste of a company’s work culture through Zoom? Can you figure out if your colleagues are cool and nice or something else, without meeting them?🙄 This is so hard to do right now. But at the same time, your satisfaction depends on these, much more than your salary. So what can you, before starting your new position? 👉🏼Explore the chemistry you have with your new boss. It is a MUST. 👉🏼Ask to meet your team even if it’s not included in the hiring process. 👉🏼Ask someone you personally know that works there 👉🏼Google it 👉🏼Glassdoor it. 👉🏼Instagram it. Yes. Culture is most visible there.   Salary is just one factor, and not the most important one.  #Never  join a company blindfolded.   #hr   #interview   #career   #hiring       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post on career growth that focuses on networking and skill-building.
output: Want to make a shift?  Switch to a new position? Venture into a new field?  DO THE WORK. Listen - talk to someone. A real person who’s been doing what you seek to do for a few years.  Understand what it takes to do their job - skills, experience, education, talent. This can validate (or nullify) your decision to pursue it in the first place. Learn - show interest.  Listen to podcasts, connect to professional groups, read articles. Get acquainted with the jargon. Know to speak the right language. It takes time.  DO - start your own project in that field. A blog. A podcast. Volunteer somewhere. Do something. This will give you plenty to talk about in interviews.  This is a MUST.  Write - post on LinkedIn or in professional groups/forums with your thoughts. Share your approach online. Comment to industry leaders. Engage.  Motivation is great.  It’s not enough in today’s market.  Do the work to gain an edge.   Job search IS a job. So is career retraining  #career   #hr   #people       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post with tips for optimizing resumes to stand out to recruiters in today's digital age. Specifically, include strategies for incorporating industry-
output: Want a better chance at that job you want to get hired for? ‘Translate’ your CV to the language the company is using. Focus on 2 elements in your CV: Title - make sure your title fits the job description. If the job description lists ‘software engineer’, don’t use ‘Backend engineer’ in your CV. If there’s a way to get a perfect match, use it. Keywords - read the full job description. Find what matters in that job. And put as many keywords as possible in your CV.  Pro tip - So many companies are using bots to screen CV. So use the EXACT same words. Use spaces before and after. Don’t let the bots rule you out.  Whatever you do, DO NOT LIE. Especially in the skill section, you will be easily spotted during the interview phase. Once you get caught lying, there’s no turning back.  Does it take time to match your CV with different positions? Yes, it does.  Getting hired is a full-time job.  #people   #hr   #skills       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about networking strategies for young professionals.
output: Getting a new job today - that’s a whole job in itself. It ain’t what it used to be.  But I still see candidates use the same old methods. The most popular one is “spray and pray” - sending your CVs to any position, regardless of how relevant it is for you. It can’t hurt, right? Wrong❌ Applying for every single job out there shows Recruiters that you lack focus, passion, and talent. Not very good qualities. Worse than that - sometimes you’ll get in the system, in which case you’ll be marked as someone who was rejected multiple times. So what should you do? 📌Research the company you want to work for. 📌Research the people who work there. 📌Find a RELEVANT job description, one that 📌you have a real shot at.  📌Research that position and try to talk to people in that company who know what it means 📌Adapt your CV to better reflect that position Then - apply✅ *This isn’t 2005 anymore* Invest time and effort, and the chances of finding your dream job will dramatically increase. #hr   #people   #linkedin       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post of approximately 300 words, in the style of a 'do's and don'ts' list, sharing tips on how job seek
output: Are you adding a message to the Recruiting person? You should, it’s worth the effort. If you do it right! The way you approach Recruiters is as important as your CV. There’s so much at stake.  Yet I still get pinged with messages that immediately disqualify the sender. Here’s how to do it: #DO : Personalize your response. Make it sound like it comes from you. Research. Give us a feeling you know what the company does, and how it relates to YOU. Be Polite. Mention any special ability you have that’s relevant. I’m always looking for a candidate with an edge.  End your message with a Call To Action. A simple ‘best regards’ isn’t enough.  #DON ’T: Use templates. I spot them immediately. Command us to do anything. You don’t work for me, I don’t work for you. Not yet at least :-) Ask us what we have to offer you. This is about offering yourself, not the opposite. Finding a job IS a job. Make the effort.   #hr   #people   #linkedin       …see more

instruction: Write a post about optimizing search results on LinkedIn. Share tips on how to appear in relevant searches and include examples of successful strategies.
output: Have you clicked on the Search Appearances feature on your profile? 🤔 You get this notification weekly, some of you ignore it while I suggest taking a deeper look.  On your LinkedIn profile, you’ll see the number of searches you appeared in.  Clicking on them gives you some handy insights. Where it shows the job-titles of the people, this indicates if you reach the right audience. Take a look at whose search you appeared in and see if those are the kinds of searches you want to be showing up in. If the people you are appearing to are unrelated to your field I would recommend seeing if you could make some adjustments to your profile to better align with the searches you want to show up in. As you can see, in my case: 📌People from AppsFlyer search my profile- Hi guys you can reach out to me over slack although I'm more available here😂 📌Most of the people work as SW developers- which is good for me because this is the audience I'm looking to hire. 📌The keywords people search for Sourcer, Recruiter, HR, and Talent are also amazing for me because this is the kind of words I want people to search and find me. instruction: Could you please summarize some common job search mistakes and suggest alternative approaches based on a recent LinkedIn post you read?
output: Do's and Don'ts in your job search I see a lot [!!!] of mistakes in the past few months and in this kind of arena you should be in your best shape! These mistakes cost a lot. #Don 't- Upload a LinkedIn post that says you've been looking for a job in the past 6 months and that everyone rejects you/ treats you unfairly in the hiring process.  #Why ? You are your own brand! If you are a brand you should emphasize your professional skills by sharing interesting content and showing interesting projects. You can get empathy from friends but LinkedIn isn't the place for that. #What  should you do instead? Ask a friend to upload a post about you as a reference or focus on side projects and show them on LinkedIn. #Don 't- Use the "Open to work" LinkedIn frame  #Why - Although it seems like a cool feature, I know recruiters who say they decline to connect requests from people with the frame in order to prevent inconvenience because they do not have jobs to offer. #What  should you do instead? Open the "let recruiters know you are open to new opportunity button", it's discreet and won't show up to recruiters at your company. And yes, marketing-wise it looks much better. All of this info is based on my thoughts research and experience. Feel free to share your opinion. Good luck!  #Jobs   #HR       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post for me that explores the shift in what job seekers prioritize when searching for employment in light of remote work becoming increasingly popular.
output: Finding a job used to be about finding a great PLACE to work in.  The culture, the environment, colleagues - for most of the people I sourced, those were more important than their salary.  Job seekers are looking for something totally different now. The focus is now on the work itself. You feel it with every candidate’s question. It’s less about feeling like a part of a community, and more about the job itself, how interesting and satisfying it can be, and how comfortable you feel doing it from a distance.  Physical distance from the office is almost irrelevant now. It opens possibilities for everyone. The world is changing. So is what people seek in their future job. #HR   #People  This is me, working 6 hours away from the office, I♥️my job.       …see more

instruction: Can you create a post on LinkedIn sharing some industry insights based on recent data? Maybe something related to the impact of remote work on employee productivity or job satisfaction?
output: Let's talk DATA! I have exciting data about the industry, 3-months post corona. I will give my insights. The basis for the information is from  AdviceMe.Il   so of course, you can not generalize it to all populations. Nevertheless it's interesting. First - the average age of people who asked for our advice: 26-33. I can explain it mostly by experience, 26-33 usually are employees at the beginning of their careers, and companies prefer to keep the seniors because they're more expensive to hire and of course, more valuable. Second, 1 out of 5 people is a software developer! Well, I was amazed by this one. I would think that SW people who are in high demand would be the last to get fired. I can explain it with 2 ideas - first, most of them are juniors /from small startups that had to close, second, AdviceMe's branding was especially oriented for tech people. Another interesting piece of data- 80% of the people who asked for our advice had at least an undergrad degree. The higher education was the fewer people there were. I guess companies won't let go so fast of people with high education. Also, 90% of people with 3rd degree had a managerial experience which is not a surprise. I want to thank  Or Hazbani   for all his help and great insights. And, 3 months later, I'm back in the office!       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post that highlights the new key factors that job seekers will prioritize when searching for employment in the wake of COVID-19. Include at least
output: The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). WDYT? What will be the new key-factors? (In the picture AppsFlyer Cares van came to cheer up our medical heroes). AppsFlyer  #covid19       …see more

instruction: Instructions: Create a LinkedIn post about working from home, highlighting the importance of being adaptable during uncertain times due to the pandemic, and share some examples of how your company
output: Why are we looking for “adaptive to change” people?🤔 Adaptive challenges refer to situations where there are no known solutions to the problem or cases where there are too many solutions but no clear choices. Adaptive challenges are by nature, adaptive, which also means they are fluid and change with circumstances. The coronavirus situation caused a lot of uncertainty, suddenly companies had to change everything in a second without base knowledge.  The companies and people who won’t adjust fast will fail. And this is why we hire “adapters”. We are 3 steps ahead of everyone else, with new creative ideas because of it.  While most of the companies try to understand how to WFH this is so last week for us😂 Well, the new routine is ahead..good luck for all of us!  I'm wearing my AF t-shirt to feel at home🏡   #wfh       …see more

instruction: Create a post about our recent collaboration with XYZ company.
output: 2 months ago, I had a problem with Greenhouse. I tried to fix it,  asked some of my colleagues in Israel and we didn't get the answer we needed. Then I thought to myself, why don't they come here? There are a lot of customers who need help. I offered  Céline Delle Donne  our Customer Success Manager to host a GH event here@AppsFlyer. 2 days ago we had the event, with more than 70 people and it was amazing! Today  Céline Delle Donne  and  Franklin Aribeana  came to a visit at our office. Thank you GreenHouse for listening to our needs, we really appreciate it. Another amazing friendship with amazing partners to our mission. Special thanks  Cory Dimitrakopoulos   Jon Stross  !       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post promoting our company's job openings in a fun and engaging way, using the themes of 'appsflyer', 'dreamteam',
output: מגייס גייס מגייס לגיוס זה הגנן גידל דגן בגן החדש!  היי לכולם, כן זה אנחנו המגניבים עם החולצות שמגייסים עכשיו לצוות שלנו בAppsFlyer.אז הנה 10 סיבות להצטרף אלינו: 1. כי יש לנו מלא בדיחות קרש מהסוג הזה (של גנן גידל..). 2. כי אנחנו הצוות הכי מגוון שתפגשו, סורסרים, מגייסים,אדמינים וכולם עובדים כצוות אחד. 3. כי אנחנו לוקחים רעיון ויוצאים איתו לפועל, לא משנה מה מי מו. 4. גם אם זה אומר שבא לנו לעשות חולצות יום לפני כנס, ובאמצע הלילה יש באג כולנו על זה והכל תמיד יהיה מוכן בזמן ( לא דוגמא ספציפית בכלל שקרתה אתמול). 5. כי אנחנו תמיד שם אחד בשביל השני, גם אם יוצאים למילואים, חלד, או חופש תמיד יש על מי לסמוך! 6. כי אנחנו אוהבים אוכל משמין אבל משחקים אותה בריאים. 7. כי כשיש למישהו בעיה, משרה שלא מוצאים לה מענה או כל דבר מהסוג הזה נשב כולנו ביחד עד שנפתור את זה. אה ונמצא פתרון מ-ד-ה-י-ם. בארור. 8. כי אנחנו סופר חדשניים. 9. כי כשיש לנו רעיון גם אם הוא הזוי תמיד כולם זורמים. 10. כי אנחנו יודעים לספור עד 10 (חזרו לסעיף מס' 1).  אז אנחנו מגייסים: Talent Acquisition Specialist  Talent Sourcer Hr Admin ואל תדאגו גם אתם תקבלו חולצה:) אה..ורק כדי לבחון כישורים מינימליים חפשו אותנו אנחנו נשמח לשוחח 3> #AppsFlyer ’sTalent #DreamTeam #Hire @AppsFlyer Inna Milbert   Assaf Schwartz   Yodan Rotholz   Nitzan Scheftelowitz   Neta Sayag   Hadas Goldenberg   Noa Kaplun       …see more            See translation

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post in the style of our previous one about AppsFlyer's recruitment efforts, focusing on the importance of personal connections during the hiring process
output: الأمور التي أحب أن أقوم بها يوم الجمعه: حملة توظيف! خاصةً أنها لهدف إيجابي مثل  Hasoub أستمتعت كثيرًا بلقائكم، بالتعرف عليكم أكثر والاستماع إلى أموركم الشخصيه. نحن هنا في  #AppsFlyer  لأجلكم! شكرًا للطاقم المبدع: أساف وإينا مدعوون للتوجه إليّ في أي وقت. דברים שאני אוהבת לעשות ביום שישי : ירידי גיוס! ובייחוד שזה למען מטרה טובה כמו Hasoub. נהניתי כל כך לפגוש אתכם, להכיר אתכם טוב יותר ולשמוע את הסיפורים האישיים שלכם. אנחנו בAppsFlyer כאן בשבילכם! תודה לצוות החלומות: מוזמנים לפנות אליי לכל בקשה. Things I like to do on Friday: Recruitment Fairs! And especially for a good cause like Hasoub. I really enjoyed meeting you, getting to know you better and hearing your personal stories. We at AppsFlyer are here for you! Thanks to the dream team:  Inna Milbert   Assaf Schwartz Welcome to contact me for any request. Daniel.Cohen@appsflyer.com       …see more

output: הכל התחיל לפני שבוע וחצי או קצת יותר, כשנסעתי לתומי בכביש החוף (נסיעה לא קלה בכלל שדורשת ממני שעות ארוכות של יוגה ומדיטציה כדי לא להתעצבן), כאשר לפתע ראיתי את הסימן 2+ וזה לא היה קלף של טאקי אלא סימון על הכביש. חשכו עיניי כשהבנתי שזה לא נתיב חדש אלא נתיב קיים שהוסב להיות "נתיב שיתופי" או במילותיי, נתיב שאינו מתאים לתושבי הפריפריה כי עם איזה שותף בדיוק אסע למרכז מעמק הירדן?. נתתי לו שם קצת ארוך אבל מאמינה שהבנתם את הפואנטה. באותו היום לקח לי 3.5 שעות להגיע מדגניה להרצליה, יכולתי בזמן הזה לטוס לאיטליה, לנסוע לאילת או לקחת טיסה ליוון אבל היי הכי כיף בעולם להיות באוטו לא? בכל מקרה בימים כאלה אני מתנחמת בעובדה שאני לא צריכה לעשות את זה כל יום כי יש לנו משרד בחיפה!  אם גם אתם הבנתם שהנתיב החדש רק עומד לעשות לנו את החיים קשים יותר ומאסתם בנסיעות למרכז דברו איתי. יש לנו מגוון משרות פתוחות בחיפה ואני ממש ממש אשמח לעזור. פיתוח פרונט, בק, QA וניהול מוצר. instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a focus on collaboration and innovation in healthcare, highlighting recent developments and partnerships in the field. Use a conversational and engaging tone, and include
output: תקציר הפרקים הקודמים: אני לא נורמלית, אני נוסעת כמעט  כל יום מדגניה בכנרת להרצליה.  בשנתיים האחרונות  Ohad Horenstein  , עם עוד כמה אנשים טובים, עסקו בהתפתחות האדירה של קהילות הייטק שקמו באזור הצפון, כחלק מפתרון רחב יותר שמטרתו למשוך הייטק איכותי לאזור. את החודשים האחרונים הקדישו למחקר מעמיק שכלל ראיונות עם אנשי HR, סמנכ״לי פיתוח, מנהלי סייטים מרוחקים של חברות ואנשים שניסו והצליחו/לא הצליחו בעבר. במהלכם ראו את הקושי של חברות במרכז לגייס סניורים ולשמר אותם ומנגד ידע מהכרות אינטימית, באמצעות הקהילות שצצו כפטריות אחרי הגשם, שיש בצפון הייטקיסטים איכותיים. אז החלטנו להקים מעין "קבוצת רכישה" של מפתחים שתהיה מוכנה להצטרף לחברה איכותית וצומחת כעובדים מן המניין, אם זו  תפתח סניף פיתוח באזור. בימים אלה החזון הופך למציאות, במידה וזה מעניין אתכם אתם מוזמנים לפנות ל  Ohad Horenstein  והוא יענה על כל  שאלה. כמובן שאפשר לפנות גם אליי ואשמח לעזור! instruction: Write a post about how companies can overcome gender pay gap.
output: A few years back, I watched a professor ask a class "If there are two equally qualified 27-year old candidates and the only difference was their gender, who should you hire?"  10 minutes in, the whole class agreed that there was no "better" candidate. The professor proceeded to tell us that the woman may be thinking about kids and go on maternity leave at that age. He started to call the woman at one point "the risk" and the lesson was to mitigate risk in hiring.  His argument was that women are inherently risky investments, even when all the data shows otherwise.   This month, I kept thinking back to this one lesson in college, equating risk to women. And now with a female Vice President-elect, I can't help but be excited for a future when women are able to prove this lesson wrong.       …see more

output: COVID-19 has caused me to reevaluate my own ego.  How could I complain when I still have my job?  How could I not continue to accelerate my career when I have all this extra free time from my commute?  Why am I not as productive when I have more time for self-care?  When I’ve been faced with tough times in the past, I’ve always assumed that I’ll just “figure it out”. output: A year ago last week, I graduated from college. That day, I united with my family after the ceremony and asked my dad, “Are you proud of me?” “Absolutely. You graduated from the school you wanted to. But you should never do something just to make me proud.  As long as you are following what you want and benefiting you and those around you, I will be proud.  You could have not gone to college at all, and I would still be proud” my dad responded.  I feel incredibly lucky and privileged to have parents that support me in what I chose to do with my education and career.  Support systems are vital.  #university   #graduation   #studentoflinkedin       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about the importance of continuous learning in the workplace, using examples from your own experience and emphasizing the value of learning from colleagues at all levels of the organization
output: I wish I understood in college that learning doesn’t end when you graduate.  I wish I understood that learning cam come from people who you report to and the people who report to you.  You don’t have to run after people that have had careers longer than you for information. People have different experiences and everyone has something to share.  I think I learned a lot more from the students that I spoke to at CSUN last week than they did from me. I am incredibly grateful.  Thank you to ALPFA - California State University, Northridge for the invitation to speak.  #publicspeaking   #university       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about your experience with a summer intern and highlight their qualities that made them stand out in the workplace.
output: “My favorite part about this internship was working under you, Natalie.” Interns are sometimes the most underrated employees at the company.  My Spring Intern,  Adriana Bernal Martinez , had her last day on Wednesday.  Mid-way through her semester, I told her that I as taking a staycation the following weekend. Her response? “How exciting! You so deserve it.” I was absolutely taken back by how well she understood how to support me.  While she thanked me for mentoring her as my intern, I should really be the one thanking her for how she taught me even more about gratitude and communication. instruction: Write a LinkedIn post in the style of a former campus editor, highlighting the growth and impact of the student community on the platform, and encouraging current students to take advantage of
output: "I can't believe you got  LinkedIn  Campus Editor. You don't even have 500+ connections." When I first joined as a Linkedin Campus Editor in 2015, I was one of about 23 in total and the only one for my school. I remember having to fight to be taken seriously. But, things have definitely changed.  USC alone now has 6 Campus Editors and 25+ people on teams expanding from this in Data & Analytics, Writing, and Multi-Media. Even only a couple years apart,  #studentsonLinkedin  have so many more opportunities to create content, connect with others, and thrive on the platform than I did. As a recent graduate, I already want to make sure that students know about their resources and are able to learn from the failures and successes I had in college. Huge props to the whole @SCampus Editing Team  for all the work they do! They are learning from the student body what students want to read on Linkedin, creating content that helps better the campus culture, and honestly are just really intelligent and strategic students. instruction: Write a 250-word blog post in APA style format discussing the importance of practicing self-compassion in maintaining good mental health.
output: I’ve been talking about  #mentalhealth  a ton recently, and I want to make sure I am putting action to my words.  That’s why I joined the 48 hour  #beinghuman  campaign to allow the minds of students around the world to be at their absolute best! I nominate  Blessing Adogame  and  Jerry Lee  to share a practice and prompt that has helped them with their own  #mentalfitness On March 24th  Kyō  will curate all the prompts generated from this campaign and create a free reflective journaling tool to help guide you through your mental fitness. My go to practice that helps me calm down during a very busy work day is to… 🔆 Turn my phone grayscale and turn on airplane mode for 20 minute increments so I can really focus on my work and be mindful of what I am doing.  One question I ask myself is… 🔆 “How far have I come from this time last year?”  We are constantly growing and it’s so important that we take time to be proud of ourselves and our progress.  #mentalhealth   #mentalresilience       …see more

instruction: Write a post about mental health and resiliency for entrepreneurs.
output: “Honestly, I’ve been working a lot on myself and getting my mental health in check.”  I asked a friend recently how she was doing in her business, and was a little taken back by this answer. There was almost an internal sigh of “me too” which she spoke about working on her own happiness. I didn't feel the same pressure to "show off" how much I work or how long my hours are. I actually found myself smiling more.  The competitive  #hustle  mentality becomes unhealthy so quickly.  Putting on events about mental health like Impact Mentality and talking more about it these past couple of months has made me realize how many people are struggling to just keep okay. instruction: User Instruction: Can you help me create a post like the one I just read? The theme should revolve around podcasts, students of LinkedIn, and hard work.
output: I started 2018 with NO JOB, NO DEGREE, and 200,000 followers on Linkedin. This year has been a complete 180 for me. Throughout 2018, I... - Doubled my follower count to 400,000 on Linkedin - Received my 3rd Linkedin Top Voice Award - Graduated from the University of Southern California - Joined the team at Studio71 - Was featured in Adweek, Inc, and more - Guest podcasted on 10+ shows - Spoke at 10+ events internationally - Hosted 5 events in San Francisco and LA - Helped launch  Impact Mentality I learned 3 major things: 1) Your goals should constantly be changing. You can't predict in January what opportunities are going to come in the next 12 months. 2) Execution is more important than your age. People will listen to a 22 year-old if they have already proven results.  3) Don't think that because you aren't going to that party on Saturday that you are "missing out". If you want to spend all of your birthday, Christmas, and New Years Eve working at coffee shops, do it.  #podcasts   #studentsoflinkedin   #hardwork   #2018inReview       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the future of workplace culture and the importance of prioritizing mental health. Use the themes of corporateculture, mentalhealth, and hardwork
output: "Hard work is no longer a differentiator. It’s the barrier to entry. I believe over the next 10+ years the real differentiator will be sustainable mental health." The number of times I have told myself "You can't put down your phone. You are replaceable. You have to work harder" has hit unhealthy levels in the past. What do you think? instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about the relevance of a college education in today's economy, sharing your personal experience and perspective, and asking for insights and opinions from your network.
output: A couple months ago, I spoke at a conference where there were more speakers who were college dropouts than college graduates. I graduated earlier this year, and with so many of my friends being college dropouts, I really started to question the value of my degree.  I put the question out to Linkedin on whether a college degree was really relevant in today’s economy.  After reading all your comments, I decided to explore the value of my degree and answer the question, “Was it really worth it?” Check out my answer in my first Linkedin article in quite some time: "Defending My College Degree" (link in comments) Thank you to everyone who showed support for my article in my post from last month and pitched in to the conversation.  #college   #studentsoflinkedin   #studentvoices   #university       …see more

instruction: Write a post for LinkedIn about the differences between Gen Xers and Boomers in the workplace.
output: Born in 1996, I sit on the cusp of Millennials and Gen Z. I remember 9/11, but I can’t remember what it was like to have a cell phone without data.  As a Gen Z-er, I focus on saving money as much as possible. But when I do spend, I spend it like a Millennial (i.e. on experiences).  I am sitting at a WorldZ session led by Viacom, and I can’t help but think about how weird it is to hear people of another generation name and define my generation.  As a marketer, I totally understand wanting to target audiences. But what I notice from these kinds of talks are the lack of Gen Z people in the room, contributing to the conversation about what they are like. I am so curious as to how the conversation about Gen Z will change once younger people start actively participating in the conversation.  #marketing   #genz   #millennials   #targetaudience   #generationaldifferences       …see more

instruction: User: Write a LinkedIn post about resilience in the face of setbacks, using personal examples and encouraging others to persevere during difficult times.
output: “What you don’t see is the years of crying myself to sleep. We go on stage and talk about how great we are, but never mention the pain it took to get here. We fail to talk about how many entrepreneurs, public speakers, and professionals have anxiety attacks on the regular. It sucks. You have to want it more than anything.” Years ago I was at an fireside chat and someone asked the entrepreneur how he gets through the times of doubt. That was his answer. While I love to share these moments on stage or with friends, let’s not forget that social media doesn’t show the nights of working and worrying. We’re all going through it.       …see more

instruction: Write a post for LinkedIn about how being part of a professional community has impacted your career, highlighting specific examples and sharing insights into the benefits of community building.
output: When I first started as the Linkedin Campus Editor at USC, I didn't even attend the college yet.    I was about to transfer from UC Irvine, and spent hours after class driving back and forth between Irvine and South LA to meet with students about the platform and how they could create content on it. By my 3rd day as an official USC student, I was on the front page of the university newspaper.  The Campus Editor Program was imperative in my career, but also in my self-image, teaching me to stretch myself beyond my "student" title and to express myself online. The community aspect made it one of my most rewarding experiences to date.    Being an alumni of the program, I have had the privilege working with  Joel Hansen  and  Annette H. , and I am proud that in August we are heading up the first Campus Editor Meetup at  LinkedIn  HQ in the San Fransisco Bay Area.    Thank you to  Maya Pope-Chappell  and all the Campus Editors that I have had the privilege of meeting along the way:  Hana J. ,  Tim Salau ,  Cornelius McGrath ,  Frederick Daso ,  Manu Goswami ,  Kate J. ,  Cheechee L. ,  Tiara Conley ,  Scarlett H. ,  Will Lawrence ,  Nathan Chiu ,  Leann Abad ,  Makenzee Frohlich ,  Casey Rosen , and so many more.       …see more

instruction: The user wants the post to convey the importance of humility in achieving success and provide actionable tips for cultivating humility. Use the style and tone of the original post as a guide.
output: A couple weeks ago, I had to check my ego.  I was telling myself that I was working harder than any of my peers and somehow deserved to be treated differently.  I didn't deserve anything. I wasn't the most successful. I hadn't achieved my goals yet. I lost perspective.  I think it's important to check our own ego. We sometimes look at goals like...
