instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a theme of 'Impact Over Title', highlighting the importance of prioritizing the significance of one's contributions in the workplace over the
output: As colleges are finishing up #graduations, most graduates will starting at the "entry level". I've seen so many of my friends job-hop, thinking that they will rise up the ranks faster.  Churning through companies doesn't mean you are on an upward trajectory. Most of these switches after 12-18 months at one company are to a similar level position. And then they get mad when their work isn't #meaningful .  To my fellow recent grads: How about we focus on the #impact of our work and the value we brought to a company  - over -  what title we have and the number of months we have been there.  We ARE acting entitled. It's time to start earning those titles through action and not words on a paper. #10tips10days  Kira Day   Bobby Umar   Lila Smith   Jake Jordan       …see more

instruction: The instruction should be related to addressing audience preferences for brevity on social media platforms, such as LinkedIn or Twitter.
output: I revisited my first popular Linkedin article, "How I Overcame My Lack of Work Experience." Here's why it succeeded ⬇ 1️⃣ It addressed what my #audience WANTED to read --- You have to find your audience, and then create content that fits what that demographic looks for on that platform.  My audience in 2015 = students, job seekers, & recruiters 2️⃣ It was SHORT --- People tend to read on the internet at a 3rd grade level. Shorter is usually better, regardless of the #algorithm .  3️⃣  It FIT the platform for the time.  --- I have people asking "How do you make a successful article in 2018? I want to write something like that one on overcoming lack of experience." Don't. That worked for 2015. 2018 favors short form posts, topical articles, and video.  What has worked for you? What has been your most viral piece?  I would love to hear from  Sam Park   Tiffany Parra   Fabio Marrama   Alexandra Galviz (Authentic Alex)  on why they think a particular piece of their content has done so well on the platform.  #10Tips10Days  Bobby Umar   Lila Smith   Jake Jordan   Kira Day       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about how finding your true passion leads to individuality in career choices.
output: When I graduated high school, college was the expected next step. For the past four years, I have had friends attend classes with me. I’ve had friends drop out to start their own companies. And, I’ve had friends succeed and fail at turning their education into work opportunities. What I learned is that college isn’t for everyone, but the  University of Southern California  was the best option for me. People have different paths to success, and each has its own unique pros and cons. I wouldn’t want my little brother to feel pressured to do something just because his friend, his brother, or older sister did it. You have to do what’s best for you. #education  #graduation       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about how to define your target audience on the platform, considering the recent changes in content consumption patterns.
output: Who's your audience on LinkedIn?  I got this question a few days ago, and while I want to say "everyone", that probably isn't true.  We all have niches that we go after or topics that we love to discuss. With LinkedIn creators pushing out so much content, the usual suspects for content on LinkedIn have been redefined and expanded. So while it's not "everyone", I've definitely struggled with defining my audience and content down to a single niche.  Have you felt the same? I would love to hear the LinkedIn community's thoughts on the expanding range of content on the platform!  Manu , Sam ,  Luke ,  Tim ,  Annette ,  Tiffany       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post with tips for defining personal value and increasing self-awareness.
output: Too many people don’t understand the value they bring.  “How do I go about making a strong personal brand?”  “How do I get noticed by employers/investors?” I was recently inspired by  Fabio Marrama 's and  Tiffany Parra 's posts on the value young people can bring and how to define that value.  There are so many of us that define our professional brand by the number of jobs or titles we’ve had. After interviewing community builders and successful entrepreneurs, it has become clear to me that it was not their title that made them confident. Instead, great leaders knew exactly how they changed the organization for the better. It’s one of the biggest reasons I tend to resent the “fake it till you make it” mentality. It may work in certain situations. You know what works in every situation? -- Working hard -- Identifying mistakes to learn from -- Becoming more self-aware — Here are some people who are creating real value for the LinkedIn community. The return you’ll get on just pressing that follow button will be incredible. Goldie Chan, Manu Goswami Tim Salau Sam Park Michaela Alexis   #DefiningValue #LinkedInCreators       …see more

instruction: The post should encourage users to share their expertise and provide examples of people who have done so. The style of the post should be motivational and inspiring, with tips on how to create valuable content
output: “'But nobody cares about my opinions,' they say. 'It would make me feel conspicuous.' 'They’ll care if you tell them something interesting,' I say 'and tell them in words that come naturally.'” - William Zinsser I've noticed that many people on LinkedIn feel like they don't have enough experience or expertise to start creating content. They leave it to this group of self-identified #LinkedInCreators as if the "creators" are the only ones able to give value to readers on the platform. I was reading Zinsser's On Writing Well for a class and found it incredibly relevant to why you shouldn't be afraid to put out LinkedIn content. While much of the platform's content can be technical, value doesn't have to come from verbose language and complicated analysis. Great content comes in many forms from many kinds of sources: students, CEOs, entry-level employees, stay-at-home parents, consultants, professors... I may be biased, but some of the best content I have seen is from my fellow students and young entrepreneurs. Check out some of my favorite people on LinkedIn who are creating real VALUE through their content and community building efforts.  -  Frederick Daso -  Tim Salau -  Tiara Conley -  Manu Goswami -  Sam Park -  Joel Hansen       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that explores the theme of uncertainty and pressure around job expectations for recent college graduates, with a specific focus on the phenomenon of frequent job hopping
output: "You don't need a great first job post-college. We're Millennials. We probably will never have the same job for more than a couple of years." I was talking to an older friend about my anxiety around graduating this May.  The advice I got was a bit discouraging. While I understand my first full-time job won't make or break my career, I wondered why I, like many Millennials, was expected to probably never have a long career at a single company.  Everyone loves talking about Millennials, and many of us have been fed an idea of whom we are:  --> self-entitled --> tech-savvy --> job-hoppers I think some Millennials have accepted job-hopping as the only realistic option for our generation to like the work we do. I always hear: "I mean, would you actually enjoy working for the same company your whole life?" I don't know yet! But I do think we shouldn't just expect to job-hop. I hope I will, at the least, stay long enough to create real, sustainable value for the companies I serve and focus more on how much I contribute than the number of years I have spent at a company. Students: Have you heard similar advice? Do you think these ideas have shaped your approach and expectations post-college? Tim ,  Kate ,  Tiara ,  Naveen ,  Annette ,  Will ,  Hana ,  Joel ,  Mrittika       …see more

instruction: ---Create a LinkedIn post with a theme related to closetheloop, bestpractices, and bestbusinesspractices, explaining the importance of regularly closing the loop in professional interactions
output: How often do you "close the loop" in your interactions with colleague, friends, partners, customers? As we move to remote work, "clear communication" will be one of our BIGGEST CHALLENGES. It will be easy for your team to be confused  about whether you are moving forward with that project or not, what the decision was on X, or what's the next step with that customer, partner, job candidate.  Taking an intentional step to "close the loop"  and clarify the decisions made becomes SO important and SO appreciated.  Closing the loop is NOT only important on initiatives/people/projects you decided to move forward with, but more importantly with the ones you decided to leave behind.  I encourage you to take a step to close the loop with the right parties (teams, customers, candidates, partners) about topics such as:  - Decision to not move forward with a particular project/partner/customer - Decision to not fund company X (applies to VCs) - Hiring decision to reject a candidate (close the loop w/ candidate) - your clear goals for a particular project and its timeline Clearly closing the loop shows our respect & dedication to others and our determination to make tough calls.   #closetheloop   #bestpractices   #bestbusinesspractices   #hiringtips   #jobsearchadvice   #management   #leadership       …see more

instruction: Can you generate a post about the future of remote work based on insights from experts in the field, highlighting its potential impact on productivity, work-life balance, and the
output: Is Remote Work Here to Stay? It surely seems like it! Brynjolfsson, who studied intersection of technology & economy for years argues a few interesting points that are worth attention (link to the full NPR article is below):  1) There's a lot of inertia in the way people work and it's quite hard to change the processes, the culture, the training, and the types of work. Unless there's a “SHOCK”, most people will tend to continue to do things the old way. In fact, pandemic seems to be the shock needed to push the world to “remote work” almost overnight. 2) Based on data, there’s a Productivity J-Curve when companies adopt new technologies and processes. First, there will be dip in productivity; then with further investments, adjustments, and adoptions there will be significant gains. So there could be more benefits of remote work to come when as individuals, organizations, and industries we nail  #remotework . #futureofwork   #workingremotely   #productivity   https://lnkd.in/gC3n2Y5       …see more

instruction: Can you help me write a LinkedIn post that discusses the benefits and drawbacks of remote work, and how companies like Twitter and Square are implementing their own versions of remote
output: Facebook  Remote Work Strategy vs.  Twitter  &  Square  Remote Work Strategy: Which one did you like better?  Twitter & Square announced that all employees have option to work permanently from home. Facebook announced that 50% of its employees will work from home over the next 5-10 years. In my view, Facebook's approach is a lot more sound and serves both current employees & future hires while still drive for the best business outcomes. Here's why?    1) Facebook acknowledge the gaps and plans to solve many of the issues such as communication & creativity through building tools & technologies.   2) Facebook plans to offer remote work to more experienced employees vs. newly graduates who need more mentoring and structure.   3) It offers Remote Work option to majority of current and future employees, but acknowledges that some roles can't be remote. It's critical to be honest and open about these types of limitations. 4) Facebook's strategy came across as data driven & feedback-driven -- based on the survey results from employees.  5) Facebook officially took a stand which enables it to establish leadership in this movement. Its decisive yet conservative approach came across as more well though out.  What do you think? #remotework   #workfromhome   #flexiblework   #futureofwork       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post discussing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the healthcare industry, highlighting trends such as increased adoption of telehealth, accelerated digital transformation
output: CEOs of dozens of healthcare companies such as CVS, Cerner, Epic, Sanofi, and Pfizer shared their views on how pandemic is transforming their businesses and the healthcare industry as a whole. Here are some of the highlights:  ➕Telehealth is the name of the game going forward. Kasier reported that it went from 18% virtual visits to 80% almost overnight. Jefferson Health went from 15 telehealth appointments a day to 3,200 a day.  ➕Speed in healthcare has changed significantly: CEO of ChristianaCare said, "We accomplished 2-3 years of work in about 2-3 weeks."   ➕Sharing early data and novel ideas has become more comfortable. ➕Many healthcare systems have seen a 35%-55% drop in revenue as they had to shut down the most revenue-generating operations and tests in the hospitals.   ➕Public-private partnerships has been unprecedented during this time and it's expected to continue. ➕Many hospitals may change their view about their supply chain and move away from 'just in time supply' to plan for more "unpredictables" in future.  #healthcare   #digitalhealth   #healthcaresystem   #healthtech   #pandemiclessons   #futureofhealth   #telemedicine   #virtualvisits   #connectedhealth   #pandemicplanning   #disruption   #managingchange   #businessimpact       …see more

Please read each article for much more in depth info; the gist of the advices are: 1) Assume meaningful drop in your revenues and top line growth for at least a few quarters to come unless you are in exceptional categories such as remote working technologies. 2) Cut down your expenses to increase your run rate. 3) Have policies for Working From Home and plans for how you will handle cases if your employees or executives end up being  #COVID -19 positive. 4) Take actions fast and be decisive. instruction: Example Instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the positive impacts of remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic. Include at least three examples of how businesses have adapted and benef
output: Despite all the madness in the world, COVID-19 crisis could potentially have some positive outcomes: 1) Many schools, particularly K-12, which haven't had online contents are rushing to create digital materials for students. That will help make a leap on e-learning across all stages of education system. 2) Many other small businesses particularly the brick & mortars (e.g. ballet or piano classes) which lost their footprints are becoming more creative, creating and distributing their contents online which could unlock new business opportunities for them. 3) Organizations in totally different disciplines are coming together in new ways to cope with the coronavirus: Zoom offers K-12 students access to its videoconferencing software for free. The Gates Foundation, Wellcome & Mastercard are committing $125M in funding to companies developing treatments for the coronavirus.  4) Many companies that haven't been fully prepared to support  #WorkFromHome  needed to move to that direction. 5) Despite "social distancing," the deep human connections will get stronger & our communities will hopefully continue get tighter. China sent medical aid to Italy & Spain. Many offer help to their neighbors on Nextdoor. #positivethinking   #beingoptimistic   #elearning   #coronavirus   #covid19   #socialdistancing       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about a person who has been a significant influence on your leadership skills, detailing specific examples of their impact on your growth, using a similar style and
output: Chris Varelas  was my 1st champion in my career! He was the Global Head of TMT, Citi Investment Banking, where I did my very first internship & then my 1st full-time job. He noticed me from the get go and connoted with me at a personal level. Through many years, he continued to be my advisor & sounding board in many big personal & professional decisions. Watching Chris in action as one of the top leaders at Citi & one of the most respected investors on the Street & in the world, taught me fundamental leadership lessons that I carried through my life:  1) As a leader, you should always keep calm & be in control of your emotions even during the most challenging times & while delivering tough news such as economic downturn of 2008 or a key executive’s departure. Teams will pick the leader’s emotions, which can help them to stay focused and confident or lose it all together. 2) Be intellectually curious. Get to know others on a personal level & always stay fun and interesting, so others care to get to know you.  3) Speak less, smile more & listen attentively. That way, when you talk and provide a point of view there’s a lot more receptivity for it.  Thanks Chris! Can’t wait to read your new book, How Money Became Dangerous.    #leadership   #leadershiplessons   #bestleaders   #founders       …see more

instruction: Create a post on LinkedIn using the theme 'bestproducts' and showcase a startup that has recently gained popularity for offering exceptional product experiences.
output: When it comes to “business and product strategies” and picking the “winners” ONLY time will prove us right or wrong. My friends, colleagues, and peers many probably remember how bullish I was about Calm early days despite the head start that Headspace had in the mindfulness category. I had done a deep dive “product analysis” on both companies early days and despite the fact that both had great products, and that Headspace arguably had more modern design, I bet big on Calm due to some superior product experiences that Calm offered (e.g. flexibility to participate in multiple programs simultaneously, the quality and relevance of its contents). Calm from early on put users’ needs / constraints in the center of the product design and development and that’s why now they are #1 app in meditation, with over $1bn valuations, and people like LeBron behind the company. Congratulations  Alex Tew ,  Michael Acton Smith , and the team!  #bestproducts   #healthandwellness   #healthandwellbeing   #meditation   #productdesign   #customerobsession   #usercentric   Lebron James       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post in the style of the given text, featuring a successful female executive discussing her experiences in leadership and work-life balance, using relevant hashtags such as
output: Powerful interview with Indra Nooyi, the Former CEO of PepsiCo; during her tenure as the CEO, PepsiCo went through amazing transformation of products and business lines and delivered incredible growth and metrics performance.  She shared invaluable nuggets of wisdom here:   1) “When you’re a female, colored woman, immigrant serving as a CEO of a large company and undertaking a transformation, there are tons of critics,” she said. “All the time you were in the public eye trying to answer the critics. So it was a "grind" all the time.” 2) Much of women’s ability to succeed at home and at work depends on existing workplace systems, which are rife with unconscious bias that “attacks women’s confidence.” 3) “All CEOs should run the company for the duration of the company, not the duration of the CEO. My success should be judged on how well my successor does, not just how well I did." Indra Nooyi  - Thank you for being such an inspiration and role model. Thank you for always keeping it real and candor which help open up larger conversations, enabling to shake the status quo.  #powerfulCEO   #femaleleadership   #worklifebalance       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post in the style of [the given post] about the importance of advocating for what's right for the success of the company, but this time
output: Happy Monday! Don’t forget that as employees, leaders, executives, board members, and investors we all have responsibilities to advocate for “what’s right” for the company. I encourage everyone to face your fears, use data and research, and stand for what’s right for the success of your company(s) every single day.  The most controversial the topic, the higher its impact (most likely), and the more important it is to stand for what’s right! Are you doing that every day?  This is very difficult in practice, as what’s right could mean different thing to various people, and what the outcome of certain decisions typically hazy. But this is were you can have “game changing” impact!  The key to do this right is to remove your biases as well as personal interests and really focus on the outcome of your decisions and behaviors on the success of the company. If the company your associated with succeed you will succeed.  #mondaymotivaton   #leadership   #leadershipgoals   #dowhatmatters       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post about Mother's Day that acknowledges the challenges some individuals face on this holiday, such as losing a mother, having strained relationships, or struggling
output: Mothers are the best gift of nature! On the Mother’s Day that’s heavily celebrated and not enough for even 1% of what any woman and Mom does for her family and kids, reading a piece from a man who recently lost his wife, the mother of his two sons, reminded me that these types of days are exceptionally hard for many, many, many people! And with the power of social media, it only got worse.  I want to send my energy and love to all the kids out there who lost their mothers, to all the kids whose mothers couldn’t be there in their lives for various reasons, and to all the kids who didn’t have good relationships with their Mom because of many different social and cultural barriers.  I also want to send my prayers to all the men who lost their partner and their best friend.  Finally, I want to send my love and best wishes to those who want to have kids and so far couldn’t for biological, financial, or social reasons.  Happy Mother’s Day to those who celebrate! Each day is a precious gift. Enjoy it to the max!  #happymothersday       …see more

instruction: Create a Happy International Women's Day post in your own words highlighting the struggles faced by women globally, while also emphasizing the need for gender equality and equal opportunities
output: Happy International Women’s Day! There’s so much work to be done to create full equality, to close the pay gap, and to resolve gender bias. It’s an attempt every day! It’s an attitude of not giving up all the time!  More power to all my sisters out there who push for what they believe in, to challenge the status quo, to struggle to balance their family obligations with high impact works, and to aim to create a better future for the next generation. Although in the Western world we’re struggling for such rights as women, unfortunately in other parts of the world millions of women are still fighting for a lot more basic rights such as not being forced to marriage at young age, being raped to save their own/their families’ lives, to go to work or to school, or being able to drive. Today, I want to invite all of us (men & women) to be more aware of our own gender bias, to acknowledge women’s ideas the same way we value those of men’s, to not harshly judge women who are wearing multiple hats in families and society by none reasonable metrics, and to reach out and donate to organizations throughout the world that support women especially those help with education and prevent domestic violence, abuse, and human trafficking. To a better & brighter future!  #HappyInternationalWomensDay       …see more

instruction: User: Hey there, AI! Can you help me come up with a social media post about incorporating self-care habits into our daily routines, specifically focusing on meditation and mindfulness
output: Happy New Year!  Let 2019 be an amazing year to bring you all the personal and professional success and growth you wish for. Do you have a new year resolution?  I have a few resolutions & goals. #1 in my list is to get back to daily meditation, the habit I built a few years ago, but lost it more recently due to being extremely busy. Wearing different hats every day as an executive, mom, wife, university lecturer, startup advisor & investor, public speaker, daughter, sister, and friend left me absolutely no time for myself.  As someone who researched mental health and the benefits of meditation closely, I know that committing to do 5-10 minutes of meditation every day will bring me the focus, calm, and clearance of mind that I need and make me more effective in everything I do. So my new year resolution is to get back to daily meditation. I want to invite you all to join me in this journey and share your experiences with me throughout the year. These are some tips on how to get started:  1) Allocate the same time every day to meditate. Ideally you meditate after an existing routine (e.g. right after you wake up). That’s the best way to build a habit. 2) Set a reminder.  3) Use one of the meditation apps - Calm or Headspace.   #health   #wellness   #meditation   #newyearresolution       …see more

instruction: Can you write a post on LinkedIn about the importance of holding male CEOs accountable, just like female executives? Let's not let them off the hook for
output: Recently, I see a few articles per week about shortcomings of Sheryl Sandberg. What bewildered me is that I don’t see as much criticism about the #1 executive, the male CEO & Founder of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg. He’s treated like a passive Chairman of Facebook at this critical times rather than the active CEO to whom Sheryl reports.  Rather than everyone focuses on the right issues, which are the technical, security, and communication problems at Facebook, they are mistakenly making the recent Facebook events about a Female Leader failure!!! Would we have the same coverages and bashing if Sheryl was Sean Sandberg! I strongly doubt... I’m sure that Sheryl made some mistakes along the way, but I can guarantee every single male and female executives make many mistakes over decades of running companies.  I can’t help but highlight that “these high power women” who take on tough roles get “substantially unproportionate fair share of blames” when things go wrong. We saw this in terms of Marrisa Mayer and we are seeing it with Sheryl Sandberg.  I really want to invite everyone from reporters to regulators to focus on the right problems and keeping the CEO more accountable or at least as equally responsible as other executives.  #leadership   #femaleleadership   #femaleexcutive   #facebook       …see more

instruction: Write a post about the importance of showing gratitude and appreciation towards healthcare workers during the pandemic.
output: Healthcare Workers’ Parallel Pandemic: Chronic Stress It’s no surprise that  doctors and nurses who go to work in an active battle zone, will,  at some point, start to feel anxious, worried, and stressed. This battle combatant is a wildly contagious disease called COVID-19. Doctors, nurses, aides, medical techs, clerks, environmental service workers feel threatened for their lives by just doing their jobs. And it is not clear if Americans really appreciate the level of risk, exposure and selflessness that all medical workers do for all of us. When I worked in a busy inner-city ER, I felt rushed, stressed and at times, worried for my safety: every now and then, some patient would come after a nurse or doctor with a knife or gun. But in comparison to treating patients with COVID? No comparison—treating patients with a highly contagious disease and with patients that are really ill, is way, way harder. My heart goes out to all healthcare workers.  The way we can support healthcare workers is by masking-up and keeping our distance. Selected Except: “We put on our masks and come to work every day because we don’t have the luxury of working from home in our pajamas, but the apathy and ennui that’s taken hold of society just makes our job feel thankless. It’s so demoralizing.”       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post with the theme 'accountability' using the style of the given text.
output: Speaking Truth to Power In classical Greece, "speaking truth to power" was known as parrhesia. The tactic is similar to satyagraha (literally, "truth-force") which Mahatma Gandhi used in seeking independence from British India. It is never out-of-fashion to speak Truth to Power.  But as writer Noam Chomsky asserts: "power knows the truth already, and is busy concealing is.”  It is the oppressed who need to hear the truth, not the oppressors. And who can argue with this?  As 2020 marched along and COVID-19 continued to worsen, all of us ‘regular’ people knew the virus was spreading and getting worse and yet, those charged with prioritizing fact, science and public wellness, buried the truth...And many more Americans are dead and sick because of it. As the promise of 2021 opens, I’m hopeful that we will have more transparency and more “Truth-Force” in managing the pandemic.  Selected Quote: Dr. Fauci described the “liberating feeling” of once again being able to “get up here and talk about what you know — what the evidence, what the science is — and know that’s it, let the science speak.”       …see more

instruction: Can you write a LinkedIn post about a recent failure in business, similar to Haven's, but instead focusing on a tech startup that collapsed due to overconfidence in
output: Hmmm. The Dream Team of Healthcare Talent Can't Score... Apparently Haven, a radically new healthcare company led by the CEO's of Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JP Morgan Chase has folded, just 3 years in... Turns out, this company, filled with the world's top brainiacs, had executed their own projects separately, with their own employees, obviating the need for their own joint venture! Why form a team if everyone is planning to score points on their own?  Could it be that these folks view themselves as so smart that they felt their plan was the best (and only) plan? Could it be these super stars couldn't compromise? Could it be that these titans couldn't appreciate that 'perfect is the enemy of good?' Or, could it be that none of them realized that 'healthcare could be so complex...'  Count me as sad. A dream crushed! I had high-hopes that new thinking would lead to new care. We certainly need new ways of doing old things--especially in health care delivery.  I'll look forward to following the story as it unfolds. Who knows...maybe soon there will be a 'tell-all' book!       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post in the style of the one provided, expressing your excitement and anticipation for receiving the COVID-19 vaccine.
output: I’m actually jealous  It doesn’t happen often, and never when talking about medicine or healthcare, but I’m jealous of those citizens who are already receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. So says the first recipient: “I can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.” That’s the feeling I want to have—joy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort—I’ve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I’m weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I’ll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do—I mean who doesn’t want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine—over the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors—clean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I’ll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected.       …see more

instruction: Provide examples of other industries that have seen 'creative cascades' during crises and how they adapted.
output: Creative Cascade at Scale  Certainly Covid-19 had been, on balance, very bad. It has, however, accelerated business goals and operations. Even in ways not planned before...like moving AA / NA meetings all virtual. Even though online rehab rose as an emergency stopgap measure, people in the field say it is likely to become a permanent part of the way substance abuse is treated.  And it turns out that ‘online’ is a highly effective tool to treat patients with behavioral health issues too. Being able to find a meeting to log into 24/7 has welcome advantages for people who lack transportation, are ill, juggling parenting or work challenges that make an in-person meeting tough on a given day and may help keep them more seamlessly connected to a support network If not for Covid, the “creative exploration” of online meetings would still have happened but much more slowly. I’m glad to finally see healthcare adopt more creative solutions, and I hope we continue to see more ‘creative cascades.’ But moving forward I sincerely hope it doesn’t another pandemic       …see more

instruction: Examples: Write a LinkedIn post about a recent study that shows how technology is being used to prevent opioid addiction, Create a social media campaign aimed at reducing teenage
output: Old-and-New Fangled Ways Help Thwart Suicides These are tricky times for sure, but it seems times have been difficult for awhile for many, if you view suicide rates as a direct expression of ‘difficult times.’ For more than a decade, health officials have watched in vain as suicide rates climbed steadily — by 30 percent nationally since 2000. Doctors have traditionally gauged patients’ risks by looking at past mental health diagnoses and incidents of substance abuse, and by drawing on experience and medical instinct. But doctors and mental health experts can’t crack the code when it comes to identifying which patients are in real danger. Turns out that AI programs explore more factors and allow healthcare professionals to identify more at-risk patients. Very good news indeed. But identify people is only half the equation...the other half—arguably the most critical half—is who is most likely to profit from an intervention...and be open to the help. Reaching people to communicate that they are not alone nor misunderstood, can happen whether the old fashioned ways or new-fangled ways... The critical element is to reach people...using AI and other predictive capabilities certainly can help reach more people and is the finest use of technology that I can contemplate.       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post about the importance of showing respect to healthcare providers during these challenging times.
output: Amen to this sentiment.  Nurses, doctors, respiratory therapists do not study hard, take exams and dedicate their lives to caring for others just to be mistreated, disrespected and not listened to by patients. I’ll say this again: healthcare professionals do not have to take care of sick people —they can refuse to care for a patient or stop working all together.  Our healthcare providers are becoming burned out and bummed out. Healthcare professionals receive profound satisfaction from taking care of patients. However, they too have limits and nothing rubs caregivers the wrong way more than patients who don’t show personal accountability for their actions and behaviors. “They tell you there must be another reason (besides COVID) they are sick. They call you names and ask why you have to wear all that ‘stuff’ because they don’t have covid because it’s not real. Yes. This really happens.”  “These people really think this isn’t going to happen to them. And then they stop yelling at you when they get intubated.” As my mother used to say: “It’s good to have an open mind but not so open that your brains fall out.” Amen       …see more

But those of us that have the strength of body and mind can help reduce the fear, and help reduce the spread of this Killer (COVID-19) by showing their love and neighborliness by wearing a mask and keeping some distance—even during these times of gatherings. instruction: For instance: Write a LinkedIn post highlighting the importance of maintaining a healthy diet and regular exercise in preventing heart diseases.Your AI response could be something like this:---
output: Got A Heart? Read This News About Blood Pressure Turns out there are “three B’s” we should focus on when we think about our heart health: Blood pressure, Blood glucose (sugars), and Blood cholesterol. People with high blood pressure are also more likely to have higher cholesterol and blood glucose levels. And this is important because heart issues still kill many more Americans than other diseases. Recent studies have found that for every 10 mm increase in systolic blood pressure, the risk of calcium deposits and cardiovascular events rose accordingly. The ideal strategy for optimal health is to focus on all risk factors — blood cholesterol, blood sugar and blood pressure.  This might be boring but it’s important: Maintaining a healthful diet, exercising, not smoking and consuming alcohol only in moderation is good for your heart health.       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post using a theme similar to 'Dogs Are People's Best Friends... Especially Now,' highlighting the emotional support animals provide during these uncertain times.
output: Dogs are people’s best friends…Especially Now.    Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don’t need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‘goodness’ looks like in all of us too!    Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April.     So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart—to commit to them…Like they will commit to you.    FTI Consulting’s Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story.       …see more

instruction: Create a post on social media discussing the issue of elitism in healthcare and how it affects access to quality medical care for all individuals, regardless of their socioeconomic
output: Don’t We All Want To Be a VIP? VIPs get the best of everything—whether it’s the best table at a restaurant, or best seats at a ball game.  And when it comes to healthcare, VIPs get the best treatment, doctors, therapies and monitoring. ‘VIP-ness’ is a feature of American medicine.  Major hospitals throughout the country have private spaces for celebrities, the super-rich and the influential. These VIPs get the most vigorous care and therapies . . . even when there isn’t enough medicine—or even hospital beds—for the rest of us ‘regular Americans.’ In my days caring for patients, every one of them wanted desperately to be treated as a VIP. Everyone wants the best medicine and best doctors, nurses and therapies. Everyone.  Selected Excerpt:  “We know that VIPs get extraordinary care — our health-care system already distinguishes between people deemed worthy of the highest level of care, versus those deemed unworthy. And that is the fact and the reality in our society.”       …see more

instruction: The instruction should provide the basic elements needed for the post, such as a specific topic related to laughter, and an explanation of how laughter can be used to address a particular health concern. However, the
output: Feeling Stressed? Anxious? Can’t Sleep? Here’s a Prescription For You. Some doctors, nurses and therapists have been prescribing laughter to help people get through this seemingly never-ending pandemic, wild fires, unemployment, and political division.. Stress and anxiety are very real health concerns and magnifies the risk of  heart attacks and strokes. Medical studies confirm that those who tend to laugh more have a lower risk of major cardiovascular illness.  Possessing a healthy sense of humor is also associated with living longer—and having more fun while being alive! So try to bring a little more laughter into your daily life—perhaps watch a few videos of pets being silly, or children playing in a puddle of water—anything that helps you laugh! Having a good sense of humor is an excellent way to relieve stress and anxiety and bring back a sense of normalcy during these turbulent times.       …see more

instruction: Create a post with statistics about how many Americans would be affected negatively by the repeal of Obamacare, highlighting specific examples of pre-existing conditions that would
output: What Should Keep You Up At Night: No Obamacare  If the Affordable Care Act(ACA), (aka Obamacare), is struck down:  1. As many as 133 million Americans — roughly half the population under the age of 65 — have pre-existing medical conditions that could disqualify them from buying a health insurance policy or cause them to pay significantly higher premiums if the health law were overturned. 2. What’s a pre-existing condition? Common ailments such as high blood pressure or asthma, any of which could require those buying insurance on their own to pay much more for a policy, if they could get one at all. 3. And!... The coronavirus, which has infected nearly seven million Americans to date, could also be cut out of getting insurance coverage  4. And, 54 million people have conditions serious enough that insurers would outright deny them coverage if the A.C.A. were not in effect. Why every single American should care:  1. Under the A.C.A., no one can be denied coverage under any circumstance, and insurance companies cannot retroactively cancel a policy. What to do? Protect this policy. Make your voice heard. Your family will thank you. Your pocketbook will thank you. (Insurance companies will not thank you!)       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the importance of body positivity that highlights personal experiences and statistics, includes relevant hashtags, and is written in a conversational and inspiring tone
output: Girls, Women, Are People Too. ..And we own a large debt of gratitude to RBG for setting the (legal) record straight. When I was in grade school, girls were not allowed to wear pants—they had to wear dresses. Nor were girls allowed to be Team Captains for any games and we were not allowed to play certain sports. In college, I had heated discussions with my dad, an educated doctor, that it was infantilizing to call Women, girls. I would say to him that once a girl started to menstruate, she became a young woman.  (This was the era of The Woman with educational books like ‘Our Bodies, Ourselves.’) And when I started my professional life, I was aware of how the men got better assignments, and how my male peers were never asked to ‘prep a room’ for an upcoming meeting, or to take notes (because ‘girls have neater handwriting’). For so long, the Working World has been slyly, perhaps unconsciously biased against women. It is much  improved from where it was even 20 years ago. And it’s not because ‘opinions naturally evolve...’ Its because of hard work. Regardless of one’s political opinion, it is true nonetheless that all Americans—and businesses—have benefited from pushing equality and justice for those of all genders, races, beliefs.  After all, what more American that that?       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about letting go of anger using the theme 'anger as a poison' and provide practical steps to overcome it.
output: Anger as a Poison Anger is a trickster—it starts out like a warm hug, providing immediate reassuring feedback. But keep it around too long, and it becomes a toxin that circulates in the bloodstream, poisoning all organs and causing self-loathing and irrational hatred for others.  Trust me I’ve been down this destructive road. At first, and for some months, the hatred provided a sense of ‘righteousness’ and ‘rightfullness.’ But I only became more and more irritable and dark.  So it goes with all hate—the hater turns to loathing of everything and everyone.  It’s critical to turn your back on anger because nothing positive comes from it. One way to do that is by breathing slow and regular, and by mentally pinpointing the ‘core nut’ of what is causing the anxiety or anger. Once the core nut is identified then mentally think through how to address that problem in your own life—not how to solve the problem flat-out.  Life gets better with less worry, anxiety and hate.       …see more

instruction: For instance, Write a LinkedIn post in the style of the given text promoting the benefits of virtual consultations for mental health services using the hashtags #telehealth and #mentalhealth
output: The Provider Will Dial-You In Now... Have you tried a telehealth visit with your doctor or nurse? Or have you (stoically) decided to have an in-person doctor’s visit? Seems like some visits are in fact better—or not worse—done online...And one of visit-types that do just fine online is talk ltherapy. The evidence so far from these equivalency trials, comparing face-to-face versus over video — every trial  shows no difference in clinical outcomes.  And, from clinical point of view, the clinician  can often learn more over video than in person, because you see people moving in their natural habitat, where they live, maybe how they interact with others. And patients like being at home. There’s a comfort level at home,  sitting there in bed with one’s dog, that allows the patient to talk about things they maybe wouldn’t have in the office, because of how painful the experience or memories are. If you are a person who might benefit from talk therapy, give it a try! If you hate it, you can always just hang up...       …see more

instruction: Can you summarize the findings from the UCSF study on virtual visits and highlight the main barriers to accessing telemedicine for older adults, particularly those in rural or
output: Virtual Visits: Friend or Foe? Technology-enabled healthcare is here to stay, and growing. No question that telehealth visits, remote patient monitoring, point-of-care testing is the  start of a much larger—and rapidly growing—area of development.  And while many are bullish on the vast benefits of digital care including reaching people who can’t access healthcare or where healthcare is scarce, or in conflict zones, it turns out to have very real limitations. Not surprisingly gaps in equity and access show-up even in this ‘virtual’ healthcare model too. (Gaps access and equity are well documented in ‘the real-world’ of health care.) According to researchers at UCSF, virtual  visits require patients to have the knowledge and capacity to get online, operate and troubleshoot audiovisual equipment and it requires internet service and cell phones or other devices.  But more than a third of adults over age 65 face potential difficulties seeing their doctor via telemedicine, with the greatest challenges experienced by older, low-income men in remote or rural areas, especially those with disabilities or poor health. Buyer beware... Selected Excerpt: “Telemedicine is not inherently accessible, and mandating its use leaves many older adults without access to their medical care.”       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post highlighting the negative impact of prioritizing personal gain over the collective welfare of society, using real-life examples to illustrate the consequences of such
output: How To Be The Most Unloved Person: Now a days it’s kinda of easy to raise the ire of fellow Citizens. Two ways that are in the news include common activities that force (by their nature) people to be in close proximity to each other. First is shopping in stores like Walmart and Costco and not wearing a mask. (What is it about Walmart?) Even though it is required to wear a mask, some individuals feel it is their ‘American Right’ to be sanctimonious, selfish and down-right mean. This is a ‘no-brainer’ way to become instantly unlovable. The second way is to board a plane and refuse to put on a mask. It’s just like if a passenger where to light up a cigarette mid-fight. Either behavior will get a person removed from a plane but nowadays, not wearing a mask during a flight will cause the pilots to turn the plane around. Wowza. Nothing could top that in turns of becoming The Most Hated Person. These types of pointless and unnecessary acts of ‘rebellion’ would occasionally happen in the hospital when patients would refuse blood draws or an X-ray. However, those patients only harmed themselves, not me. Here’s how to avoid being the most despised Person: Wear a mask, have respect for your fellow Americans and just simply return to being a decent human being.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about a recent trend in the healthcare industry that highlights how some medical professionals are prioritizing their own financial gain over the well-being of their
output: Surprise! And Not In A Good Way.... You might think that when you go in for surgery at your favorite hospital, they have all the staff and expertise to actually ‘do’ your surgery...but you’d be wrong! Turns out—kinda on a whim—the surgeon can decide to add independent consultants to help him/her with the surgery! And those added consultants—called surgical assistants—don’t have a medical or nursing license...And, they are often not covered by insurance.  So the doctors and surgical assistants make more money, and the patient is stuck with a big bill. I can’t imagine going to a surgeon who needs to add outside help to perform any surgery—hospitals have very strong OR certified special nurses and techs who are experts in operating rooms...and they are covered by insurance! So what’s going on? Another way private equity companies are ripping off the Healthcare Patient.   Some of the larger surgical assistants Private equity firms often target segments of the health care system where patients have little choice in who provides their care. The private equity business models include keeping such helpers out-of-network so they can bill patients for larger amounts than they could negotiate from insurance companies. Take Away: Ask if ALL of your surgical team are in-network.       …see more

instruction: Create a celebratory post in honor of a groundbreaking individual who recently achieved a remarkable feat, highlighting the impact of their accomplishment and invoking inspiration to others striving to
output: Women Pioneers—Womaneers—Should Inspire All Who Aspire To Be Their Best Selves  The U.S. Navy has its first Black female tactical jet pilot, Lt. j.g. Madeline Swegle. First Ever—This is news all Americans should celebrate! There was another history-making military achievement this week. A female Army National Guard soldier graduated from the grueling Special Forces, making her the first woman to join the Green Berets. I was raised in a family where both my mom and dad told all their children that, with hard work and grit, we could be anything we wanted to be. These were Big Words coming from people who lived in an era when women typically stayed home to care for ‘the family.’ And when I met my husband, I learned that his Great Aunt was Emilia Earhart—a true and early—Womaneer! For those that aspire to be more, or do more, I say this: Take a breath, square your shoulders, and walk forward—and keep going till you reach your goal. Selected Excerpt: "Swegle is the @USNavy's first known Black female TACAIR pilot and will receive her Wings of Gold later this month. HOOYAH!" the post states.”       …see more

output: Walking The Patient-Centered Walk...(Or Being All Talk...) This is the response I got from my doctor today when I asked her (or her team) to find my blood type in my medical records. I tried to find the information myself but it’s not visible to me—the patient! I’ve been part of this same Integrated medical health system literally my entire life, having been borne there. I’ve had surgery and other procedures there so I know they have this information. So what’s this answer about? Laziness and not actually being patient-centered. This is a perfect example of why patients and consumers are finding alternatives to legacy healthcare—to find organizations that actually care about the individual. instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the impact of job loss on healthcare coverage during the pandemic.

This is what happens when healthcare insurance is tied to employment instead of just being a ‘product’ individuals/families can buy, like any other insurance product—think home insurance or car insurance...People don’t get those products through employers, so why force health insurance to be bought through employers? Nevertheless, no federal COVID-19 legislation signed into law has attempted to restore or preserve comprehensive health insurance. instruction: Write a social media post on the importance of discipline for future benefits, with specific examples and statistics to support your argument. Use a conversational tone and keep it concise
output: Habit and Discipline: Borrrring—But... No one likes to do things that are hard or uncomfortable or not fun! I mean, who likes to dental floss or diet? I get it. But people  who are able to think beyond ‘the here-and-now’ do it all the time.  They can put off something they want ‘now’ because they can think about ‘later.’  Often when I hear people talk about why they quit smoking or lost a lot of weight, it’s often because that person is thinking about being alive to see their child’s graduation, or because they have a personal goal of climbing a mountain or running a 10K. Wearing a mask is absolutely the same: doing something uncomfortable ‘now’ for some benefit that accrues ‘later...’ My advice? Pick a goal that is in the future and adjust your behavior to ensure you and your loved ones are alive and well to realize it... instruction: Write a social media post in a similar style to the one shared about healthcare pricing transparency, but for a different industry or topic. Make sure to highlight the benefits and any
output: In Healthcare, There Are Now Prices Listed Do you ever go to a restaurant or hardware store and buy things without knowing what it will cost? Absolutely not. There are always prices listed. Until now, when you go see your doctor or go to the hospital for a scheduled procedure, consumers never (ever) knew what it would cost. And if you ever asked anyone working there what something would cost, they could never tell you—because they didn’t know either!  Now consumers and patients get to see a price list for services before they are stuck with a bill! Just like absolutely every other thing— Under the rule, hospitals must list standard prices for 300 “shoppable services,” as well as the lowest prices they will accept from consumers paying out of pocket. Guess whose unhappy? The new price transparency rule is receiving tremendous pushback from the hospital industry. Guess whose happy? All of us that need health care services. And it’s especially  important if you pay out of pocket or have a sizable deductible. Finally some good news.       …see more

instruction: Can you summarize the LinkedIn post 'Do We Really Need All Those Doctor's Visits?' in your own words, and provide some statistics or examples to support the
output: Do We Really Need All Those Doctor’s Visits? No... And it took a pandemic to prove it to all of us...again.  Experts have been telling us for years that at least 15-30% of healthcare and procedures are simply unnecessary. And not only unnecessary, but could cause other medical problems due to the chance of experiencing a medical error.  Why Is there so much unnecessary care? Because  care is driven by many forces: “defensive” medicine by doctors trying to avoid lawsuits; a reluctance on the part of doctors and patients to accept diagnostic uncertainty (which leads to more tests); the exorbitant prices that American doctors and hospitals charge, and the pervasive belief that newer, more expensive technology is always better. Consider this: Perhaps Americans don’t require the volume of care that their doctors are used to providing. Know what I say? Stay home to get better.       …see more

Data from the research firm Nielsen that tracked Americans’ grocery buying from March to May bore this out. Campbell’s reaped a 93 percent increase in sales of its canned soup, General Mills, breakfast cereal jumped to 37 percent in the third week of April and Americans continue to by  51 percent more frozen waffles, pancakes and French toast from Kellogg’s. And so on. Tricky advertising will continue since the Companies are on the record: They want to ‘Recapture Impulsiveness.’ Which means getting the consumer to purchase fundamentally unhealthy and non-valuable foods. Don’t do it. Don’t allow these times of uncertainty get under your skin—literally. Highly processed foods are called ‘food stuff’ for a reason—because they are not real food. instruction: Create a LinkedIn post sharing your personal experience and appreciation for spending time in nature, highlighting its positive impacts on physical and mental health, and encouraging others to prioritize outdoor
output: The Joy of Outdoors I was a chubby girl. Of course others told me so, maybe not in direct ways. For example, I was always picked last for group activities. So I started running. At age 13. It would be the second biggest transformative event of my youth—the first being a 10 day backpacking trip I went on at age 14, sponsored by my school. Ever since then, I’ve benefited wildly. Running and hiking have given me fresh air, time for reflection, and a better cardiovascular system.  And while I joined a gym years ago, the second the weather turns nice, I’m outside. So now that gyms are closed, I’m not sure I’m going back. Being ‘forced’ to spend time outside is, well, a gem.  Seeing blue skies, noticing how the grass shifts in the breeze, seeing new flowers is the stuff of real-life.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a focus on the importance of global health cooperation and funding, particularly during times of crisis such as pandemics. Use persuasive language to
output: Why America Needs The World Health Organization This might fall under the category of ‘boring but important,—‘ not every thing can be fun-and-games... The World Health Organization (WHO), founded in 1948, has a broad mandate to “act as the directing and coordinating authority on international health work” within the United Nations system. It is made of 1948. Sound like something we need right about now? When we have a Global Pandemic? YES is the answer. Yes. But the US Government is cutting funding and America is the largest funder. This is like if you fired your doctor because he gave you bad news. Sure, it happens but not to people who are critical thinkers and want to succeed. But this administration—and its talking heads— are pointing fingers, trying to blame them for—well, does it matter? Claims of slow response, failure to mobilize resources, failure to perceive the deadly impact of this global disease sounds like a complaint against this administration, not WHO. We need all the smart scientists, doctors and data now more than ever. In fact everyone is counting on them to develop vaccines and medications. We certainly are not looking to Talking Heads to develop these drugs and tests.  Keep funding WHO. Otherwise we are lighting a match to burn down our own homes.       …see more

instruction: Write a post highlighting the dangers of politicizing public health during a crisis, using examples to support your argument and encouraging readers to prioritize scientific evidence over political ag
output: Traditionally, it’s been the CDC’s role to give the public and local officials guidance and science-based information during public health crises. During this one, however, the CDC has been sidelined.  But worry not! The CDC—which, let’s remember, stands for Centers for Disease Control!—actually has a detailed plan for reopening all aspects of businesses and social services!  And yet....The Trump administration shelved this very document created by our nation’s top disease investigators.  Let me ask, ‘When you get sick, do you call your doctor’s office for medical care, or do you call your politician for medical care?’ Why on earth would we care what a political organization has to say about a pandemic? There used to be a joke among those of us in medicine.  We would say that doctors always thought they were qualified do other—unrelated—jobs, like run hospitals even though they didn’t know how to open an excel file.  Trust me when I say that anytime someone extends themselves outside of their training and experience, it never works out optimally. My advice—as a trusted healthcare profession—is this:Find the CDC guidelines for reopening, print it or save it, and use it...and use only it to guide your every move.       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post emphasizing the significance of learning and respecting others' perspectives, using examples from current events or personal experiences to support your argument.
output: “Personally I'm always ready to learn, although I do not always like being taught.” Winston Churchill   Take for example the ‘new thing’ we’ve all had to learn about face coverings: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says "everyone should wear a cloth face cover when they have to go out in public" to help slow the spread of the Corona Virus.  Mind you almost 70,000 Americans have died of this disease so far.   And yet, some people just don’t want to learn.  The response in the city of Stillwater Oklahoma which is requiring citizens to wear face coverings (like so many other states),  threatened store employees with physical violence and showered with verbal abuse.  Learning and ‘being taught’ new things is at the core of advancement—or ourselves and for our country. And to my way of thinking, learning new things is foundational to the American Experience and what makes this country unique among others.   So, when did American Exceptionalism turn into ignoring science, fact and honoring The Self over Others?    Here’s what I learned as a child that was hard-taught but that still works today: ‘Be kind and considerate of others, and don’t be a selfish idiot,’ and you will be loved by your family, friends, co-workers and neighbors.   Why is that hard to learn?       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the vulnerability of rural hospitals during the pandemic and potential solutions to address this issue. Your post should include statistics on hospital closures in different states and
output: What Are Hospitals to Us? Most of us don’t think too much about hospitals, that is unless you need and use them. And when you do need them, well, you need them. And often you need them close to your home and in your community. But even as hospitals in cities like New York City and Detroit have been deluged with coronavirus patients, many rural facilities now have the opposite problem: their beds are near-empty, their operating rooms are silent, and they're bleeding cash. During these very irregular times, and unlike ‘normal,’ many hospitals are seeing way less patients than normal. Either because people are fearful of going to them for fear of catching  COVID-19, or also because all elective (non-urgent) surgeries and other procedures have been postponed. More than 150 hospitals and hospital systems around the country have already furloughed tens of thousands of employees. One reason why rural hospitals in some states have shut more hospitals than others: The states that refused to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act program have seen more hospital closures. Meanwhile, the pandemic has made it even harder for already financially vulnerable rural hospitals to survive. I’d be very sad if my local hospital closed. Especially if I worked there—       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post expressing gratitude towards teachers during the pandemic using a heartwarming or inspiring message and a relatable example.
output: Why I know Doctors and Nurses Will Save Us... Because Adam Sandler said so.  From somewhere deep in his apartment, Adam Sandler’s mind is summarizing why we all love these healthcare workers—and it’s because they humanly, calmly, do the daily work of ‘saving lives and stamping out disease.’  Saving lives and stamping out disease is what my doctor-father would say every day after work, when I’d ask him ‘How was work Dad?’ My father’s steady, no-ego approach to medical practice, and hearing stories over dinner about treating patients, formed my opinion (at a very young age) that healthcare and science were the most important careers one could have. This has been true for my entire life and it’s even truer now: all healthcare workers and those doing ‘first response’ work are our National Treasures. If you want to put a smile on your face, watch the video of Adam Sandler singing high praise to our doctors and nurses!       …see more

instruction: Hey, could you generate a post similar to the one I just read on LinkedIn about hope and responsibility during these difficult times? The author shared some inspiring stories about kindness
output: A Few of My Favorite Things In the midst of this (hopefully) once in a lifetime pandemic, there are,surprisingly, loads of good-news stories including: -The story of the oft-shunned African migrants in Italy helping provide fresh vegetables to...Italians! —The story of a low-income-serving grocery store owner, giving away groceries to all his customers...and he plans to do it again. Why? Because he said, ‘It’s the right thing to do.’ —Many local stories of people sharing their bottled water, TP and other items with total strangers. —Stories of families singing together. Friends connecting virtually and neighbors helping neighbors like never before. This gives me hope and a warm heart.  That said, in my ‘Least Favorite’ column, there are still states that do not require ‘shelter-in-place,’ and churches encouraging large crowds of people.  Here’s the thing about diseases and viruses specifically: they are equal-opportunity infectious agents. If they had personalities, you’d find them to be non-partisan, non-sexist, non-racist, non-religious, non-anything. They love everything and everybody. And that’s the problem.  So let’s get more good stories of people (and leaders) being smart about social distancing and less stories of people believing they can rise above this virus.       …see more

output: These Are A Few of my Least Favorite Things: In times like these I’ve been uncertain how to feel...some times I feel scared, anxious and (to be honest), slightly paranoid. Perhaps my mood swings are due to a generalized uncertainty or because I feel that too few of our leaders are acting with confidence and facts. But I’ve found a tonic to my ills and his name is Dr.Fauci. And that is because he represents Science and Facts. And in these times, science and facts are the true messengers and Dr. Fauci and other medical professionals and researchers are helping us understand the viruses’ language. They are the people who represent hope, grace and goodness.  In times like these, we need to be singing from the same sheet music listening to only one conductor—think of it like this: We are all in the Pandemic Choir and Dr. Fauci is our conductor. Any one who wants to harm him (for whatever crazy reason), harms all of us.  There is no choir without him and people like him. instruction: Write a post highlighting the significance of being a follower during uncertain times, emphasizing the role of followers in upholding moral values and respecting social norms
output: Why Followership is More Important than Leadership. With everything going on (you know what I mean...) there seems to be an uptick on advice on Leading or Leadership. Topics like  ‘How to be a Good/Great Leader During Times Like These’ is everywhere.  Helpful thoughts certainly but I’d suggest what is really needed right now is advice on ‘How to be a Great Follower,’ and ‘what Does Followership Look Like in Times Like These.’  First off, without Followers, Leaders fail. Leaders without Followers are either phonies, extremists or untrustworthy.  The role of Followers is not talked about enough. Followers alone are responsible for the success of Leaders. Without followers there are no leaders. For any project or organization to succeed, there must be strong, ethical people who willingly and effectively follow.  In these times—and in the context of Global Public Health Uncertainty—Followers uphold moral, cultural and community rule-of-laws. We are the Effector Arms and Legs of all the right and correct actions that must be taken. But it means honoring social distancing. But it also means considering  our neighbors and community members by not hoarding or becoming rude, disrespectful or unethical. So go and do the right thing...And as my Dad would say, ‘Stay Out of Trouble.’       …see more

output: In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‘personal digital medical records’ are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. “Patients should have control of their records, period. Now that’s becoming a reality,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. “These rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.” Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions —a good first step for all of us.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a focus on exposing the neglected conditions of elderly care facilities and call for urgent action from policymakers to address this critical issue. Use
output: Sloppy—and dangerous—Care is What Our Seniors are Getting. In recent years, the federal government has been ramping up the standards for nursing homes, but inspectors remain frustrated by the prevalence of sloppy or nonexistent handwashing.  4 in 10 nursing homes have been cited for an infection-control lapse. And these are at the ‘5 Star’ places. Workers are not washing their hands as they moved to the next patient, or failing to don masks, gloves and gowns when in the rooms of contagious patients in isolation. Why? Many of the nursing homes are privately owned or backed by for-profit owners who cut staff and pay low wages. So it’s hard to get well trained, dedicated staff. In my opinion nothing is more ugly than a country that abandons their responsibility for it’s aging citizenry.  Ensuring patients are safely cared for in a dignified manner is all of our responsibility. As family members visiting nursing homes you should ask the aides if they’ve washed their hands prior to touching your loved one.  Hand washing is the Number One best activity to prevent the spread of Infection so ask about it every single time anyone walks into a room. I’m dead serious.       …see more

instruction: How can we promote optimism in our daily lives based on the information provided in the text material?
output: What Type Are You? Glass Half-Full, or Half-Empty? People who view life as ‘glass half-full’ tend to be more optimistic and believe ‘things will work out.’ Those of us who are ‘glass half-empty’ are always preparing for things to go awry... But an increasing number of recent long-term studies have linked greater optimism to a lower risk of developing cardiovascular disease and other chronic ailments and to fostering “exceptional longevity,” a category one team of researchers used for people who live to 85 and beyond. I guess this makes  sense...Optimists tend to take better care of their health. They’re more likely to exercise and eat better and are less likely to smoke, while pessimists bathe their bodies in damaging stress hormones! The good news is that we can change the way we think! The first step is to learn to catch yourself when thinking negatively—just that thought alone can can help turn ‘glass half-empty’ people into ‘glass half-full’ people! Selected Excerpt: “It’s never too early and it’s never too late to foster optimism. From teenagers to people in their 90s, all have better outcomes if they’re optimistic.”       …see more

instruction: User: Can you help me write a social media post about the vulnerability of frail patients during surgeries? I'd like it to include some statistics and recommendations for improvement
output: If you are ‘senior,’ and you need surgery, read this! Recently published in JAMA Surgery, has found that frail, older adults are more likely than other patients to die after even supposedly minor procedures — and even when the surgery goes well, without complications. Frail, older patients frequently undergo such operations, which surgeons tend to see as routine, simple fixes — but may not be. “Our data indicate that there are no low-risk procedures among patients who are frail,” according to new research. instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about someone's act of kindness towards a group of individuals who may not be as fortunate or privileged as others. The post should highlight the impact of

Mr. White is a barber who gives hair cuts to those with dementia—in the nursing home.  Dementia has been recognized as a public health priority by the World Health Organization, and for good reason. According to the WHO, there are 50 million people living with dementia around the world, with an additional 10 million being diagnosed every year.  There is currently no cure for dementia, so healthcare providers are turning to life-enrichment alternatives for their patients, meaning services like White's are likely to increase. There is verbal bullying and passive-aggressive and cyber bullying and of course, there is physical bullying. What to do? Here are a few strategies: Pitty them—assume they are screwed-up and try compassion.  Pick your battles—strike back verbally or through formal complaints. Powerful doctor and hospital groups are stepping up their opposition to those measures and have mobilized lobby lawmakers and their staff against the effort. Sure, everyone needs to get paid for work done but when you go to the ER after being hit by a bus, you can’t know if the ambulance is taking you to an “in-network” doctor or hospital. instruction: Write a social media post about healthy eating habits that highlights the negative impacts of consuming highly processed foods while promoting the benefits of a plant-based, whole-food diet.
output: You Are What You Eat—Regardless Of Politics  We all know that the more processed the food, (meaning food that has added the more salt, saturated fats, sugar, refined flour) the worse it is for us, leading to diabetes and obesity.  It’s also clear that more red meat is no good for our heart, or blood pressure. Diseases such as atherosclerosis, heart disease, stroke, obesity and Type 2 diabetes are called Lifestyle Diseases because they are caused by eating processed foods.  The government is limiting scientific input to the 2020 dietary guidelines, raising concerns among, well every one like scientists, doctors, nutritionists and parents. So why limit what the USDA can study and recommend? Well, because there is one group who thrives off of high-sodium, high-sugar, high-saturated fat and highly processed foods and it’s the  large food companies. Sadly we probably cannot look to the Food Pyramid as our nutritional ‘North Star,’ so look to what farmers and grandmas have been doing—eat simple, veggie-based, whole-grain and beans foods more often than not and you’ll be in strong health! instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about dealing with the blues after the holidays, using examples from the given text and suggesting practical tips to overcome the feeling.
output: Back to Work Blues? It’s a Real Thing. It’s Monday morning and Summer is over...You've got months before it’s Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays and Surprise!, you are feeling cranky. Doctors and mental health workers don't officially have a name for this. There's nothing specific in the official manual of mental disorders. But the Twitterverse calls your sadness  #backtoworkblues  or  #holidayblues . Kids get it too. You know the feelings—cranky, uninspired by a million emails, unmotivated to deal with trivial (or big) work assessments, uninterested in petty complaints by co-workers and all you want to do is return to your summer lounge chair! What to do?   First off, know that transitions between play and work are rough, so give yourself a little breathing room to be OK with it being a bit tough for a period.  Consider booking another short getaway you can look forward to, ease back into work, add something new into your life like a cooking class or new exercise. Remember, there’s always next summer to plan for! Selected Excerpt: "The stark contrast of the joy and freedom of family and friend time with the drudgery of answering a zillion work emails, can be hard on your emotional well-being,"       …see more
