output: American Ingenuity: Get Healthcare in Mexico  So, American doctors, American healthcare organizations, American insurance companies and American employers are figuring out how to provide excellent healthcare—-Do it in Mexico!... Yup—if American healthcare has become to expensive (or greedy) then the market will self-correct to maximize efficiency ...this is capitalism at its purest. But in this case we end up undercutting our own selves... Sure, we can have our own employers allow us to  hire our own American doctors to perform surgery in American certified hospitals located in other countries because it will be less expensive, but doesn’t that just seem like a big work-around to a broken system? Not to be too simplistic, but why not just lower the costs and fees on everything here, in our own country, so we can stay here to get our care?? Selected Excerpt: “The high prices charged at American hospitals make it relatively easy to offer surgical bargains in Mexico: In the United States, knee replacement surgery costs an average of about $30,000 — sometimes double or triple that — but at the Mexican hospital , it is only $12,000...” ——— LinkedIn Top Voice Healthcare 2015, 2016, 2017       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post emphasizing the difference between a healthcare organization and a healthcare service. Use examples and statistics to support your argument.
output: Truth in Headlines Please!   I saw this headline—and thought: ‘I didn’t know Uber is also a Health Care Organization!’  And then I read the article—Uber did not build a health care organization...they added ride services for patients. Two points: it’s great to have rides for people who need to get to and from their medical appointments.  But...proving rides does not equal being a health care organization!. Doctors, nurses, hospital administrators, risk managers, technicians and other dedicated health care staff who work diligently to help patients in their medical care, recovery and illness, work in a health care organization.  And running one of those organizations is hard work—patients and families rely on those people to be dedicated, accurate , evidenced-based, accountable and compassionate. When you are an organization like a hospital that understands and lives the daily stress and responsibly for lives lost-and saved—why then, and only then can you declare your self a health care organization! Until then, you are a ride hailing company that has an important population carve-out. —- LinkedIn Top Voice Healthcare 2015, 2016, 2017       …see more

output: What’s Wrong With Me? You Might Be Lonely As we all knew, being sad, anxious, lonely is bad for our health. People who are lonely live shorter lives and are more at risk for chronic illnesses like heart disease, depression, and dementia.  Weirdly, even with so many on-line connections, a full fifth of Americans feel lonely. Ways to feel less isolated and lonely? Connecting into your  ‘real community,’ yet that can be challenging for many, especially older people or people who don’t have a lot of extra time. So health insurance companies are adding ‘togetherness’ care plans which help connect patients with services and, well, help them feel less lonely! Why are insurance companies doing this? Turns out if you treat Loneliness like a chronic condition, you can reduce unnecessary hospital readmissions—hence saving the insurance companies loads of money. output: Not All Hospitals Are Created Equally.Not By A Long-Shot. This article highlights a very sad story of a poorly run pediatric heart program at a highly prestigious children’s hospital. Many of the problems at this hospital are similar to problems found at other hospitals that have specialized programs, including perhaps the biggest issue: not treating enough patients per year (or case volume) to develop the needed medical expertise to reliably get safe patient outcomes. Reaching adequate case volumes to keep up skills is a challenge because so many hospitals are competing for patients — these programs are an important driver of profits, so hospitals want to keep them going. Some geographic regions (and many countries) have creative ‘regional hubs’ so that an area could only have as many cardiovascular surgical programs as the population could support...Unlike what we see in this country where competing programs might only be a few miles apart. What to do? Look up publicly reported data (Hospital Compare is a good source), ask doctors for their complication rates and ask how they compare to other, top-notch programs... instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the issue of elder neglect in society, using a personal experience to illustrate your argument.
output: Who is Responsible For Our Old People? While riding public transit today I ran across this elderly man who was displaying clear signs of dementia and appeared disheveled. He posed no risk to himself or others. Not sure if he was on his way to or from somewhere. Not sure if anyone wondered when he’d arrive or worried if he didn’t show up.  He seemed utterly alone, which seems painful given his senior years and confused state. Maybe we don’t (collectively) care...but somehow it struck a sad cord in my heart as I watched him point to no one and talk to no one. At one point in time, he was someone’s child and might be someone’s father. Where are people like this supposed to live? Who is supposed to help them. Where is our humanity—and even absent that—where is our infrastructure which should exist in a democratic society which holds that all people are created equal and deserves compassion?       …see more

instruction: Can you write a LinkedIn post about the challenges faced by neurodiverse individuals in the workplace and suggest some accommodations that companies can implement to support them?
output: Find it Hard to Concentrate at Work? Maybe You Are Neurodivergent. Ever wondered why its so hard to concentrate at work? Two reasons: firstly, cubicles and open spaces are noisy, distracting and communal-encouraging “drop-in” meetings and interruptions. And secondly because not everyone is ‘wired’ to handle so much chatter and unpredictability. Neurodivergence describes the variations in the ways our brains function, and encompasses people on the autism spectrum and people with ADHD or dyslexia. The term has been expanding to include those with anxiety, depression, OCD, and PTSD—anything that makes a person think a bit differently.  And this can make typical work spaces and work flow challenging. However there are adjustments in a work setting that can be made, include allowing more time working from home, adjusting neurodivergent workers  start time and end time.  Allowing for this flexibility in scheduling and letting people do what they need to do to cope with noise or environment—without judgement. Selected Excerpt: “Around 50 to 75 percent of autistic people with higher education are unemployed. The unemployment rate for people receiving public mental health services is approximately 80 percent.”       …see more

In general, people can be very bad at recognizing the emotions of themselves and others, which in turn leads to a lot of misunderstandings and missteps. In China, Pu’er tea, made from the leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant, is created according to a specialized process and many believe in it’s unique health benefits, such as improvements in heart health and reductions in cholesterol levels.  It’s also said that Pu’er tea can help promote weight loss, enhance eyesight, stimulate circulation, and soothe hangovers! Coffee however has been shown to lower the risk of some cancers, including endometrial cancer and nonmelanoma skin cancer. A study of more than 500,000 people across the world concluded that coffee drinking was associated with reduced risk of death from various causes Tea however gets the leg up for one reason only: the plethora of powerful antioxidants and polyphenols.  Yes, coffee has them, too, but tea often has them in higher concentrations. I’m still a devoted coffee drinker but have added Pu’er tea to my weekly hot beverage line-up!       …see more

Reframe the situation—For example if you are ‘bummed out’ you can’t play tennis for three months, think  ‘now an opportunity to read those books I’ve been wanting to read’ or to ‘learn to cook those four dishes that I’ve  just haven’t gotten around to...’ Truth is there’s lots that can be done during this ‘down time,’ so think ‘Crisis as Opportunity.’       …see more

instruction: Write a post about how smartwatches can help detect health issues, but caution should be exercised due to the possibility of false positives.
output: Oops...Before you fall in love (with technology)make sure ‘they are true-blue...’ Turns out your Apple Watch has been cheating on you! According to a massive new study just published, turns out that the pulse sensor in Apple Inc.’s watch helped detect a heart-rhythm disorder in a small number of users but may have caused false alarms for others.  As is true when it comes to physiology—and pathophysiology—our body systems are always searching for homeostasis. Meaning, our bodies are always trying to function normally and within a small band of performance. Yet normal variation exists in performance that are no big deal... Like your heart doesn’t beat exactly the same all the time. And it’s fine. Normal variation! But the Apple Watch might be mis-characterize these beats, and label them as more significant than they are. This is called a false positive! So you need to watch out for being over-treated or mis-treated if you seek care for this ‘normal’ variations. Selected Excerpt: “The study’s mixed findings hinted at the potential of “wearable” gadgets to detect asymptomatic health conditions in people that might otherwise go unnoticed.”       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a compelling theme emphasizing compassion for animals, highlighting the necessity to replace animal experimentation with advanced technologies like computational modeling, while citing relevant
output: Why Are Animals Still Used by the FDA? Dogs and primates are still used as disposable test subjects, confined to small pens, in labs, subjected to all kinds of experiments. I’m very (very) happy to learn that the FDA is making important progress to find alternative approaches to studying and testing new drugs and vaccines. While I understand the historic role animals have had as “lab rats,” there are simply too many options available now (like sophisticated computer-based modeling) to warrant the use of animals in scientific experimentation. If we view ourselves as a kind and decent Society, then we must support the move towards banning animal-testing.  If animals could talk, what do you think they’d want? Go ask your own dog or cat how they might feel about being poked and prodded and kept in a pen their whole lives! instruction: Can you summarize the main message of the LinkedIn post about nurses and highlight its significance in the healthcare industry?
output: What’s The Deal? We say we ‘love’ nurses but we are not willing to pay for their technical and clinical expertise? To all the Health Care and Hospital CEOs: Do you value getting high scores on Quality, Harm and Patient Experience Publicly reported goals? Well guess who’s making those high scores possible? instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that emphasizes the importance of treating elderly patients with respect and dignity, highlighting the negative impact of ageism on healthcare outcomes, and proposing practical
output: Older Patients Are People Too I’m so pleased to read about medical schools adding courses in geriatrics that include hearing from and engaging with healthy seniors. When you are a clinician, you only see people when they are ill, so it’s easy to believe that the only type of senior citizens that exist are sick ones. So it’s critical to realize that mostly people are healthy and living full lives—even people who are in their 70’s, 80’s, and beyond!  Dispelling the notion that seniors are ‘too old to treat,’ or ‘should expect to be tired, lazy or depressed,’ is critical to being a great doctor or nurse. Not long ago when my mother was ill and in a rehab unit, her doctor told her she only had a week or so to live. Her reply was ‘If you stay my doctor that’s true.’ She ignored his advice to get into Hospice care and she continued to live another 2 years.  Selected Excerpt: “Unfortunately, most education takes place within the hospital,” he told me. “If you’re only seeing the hospitalized elderly, you’re seeing the debilitated, the physically deteriorating, the demented. It’s easy to pick up ageist stereotypes.”       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post that highlights the increasing trend of decline in skilled nursing facilities due to high medical error rates and substandard treatment. Provide examples and statistics to support your
output: I say ‘So Long, Sayonara and Adios’ to Skilled Nursing Facilities. One-in-three patients in skilled nursing facilities suffered a medication error, infection or some other type of harm related to their treatment—much higher medical error rates than hospitals. And 60% of the errors are preventable according to physician reviews. The injuries and deaths were caused by substandard treatment, inadequate monitoring, delays or the failure to provide needed care (According to CMS) With over 70% of the Skilled Nursing Facilities (SNF) operating as for-profit, and with pressure from company owners to maximize revenues, it should come as no surprise that ‘word on the street’ is to stay away from SNF unless there is a very rare exception. (Yes, I know there are some ‘good ones’ out there by data will tell you it’s about 5% of the market.) The rise in post-acute options like Home Care is hopeful, and promises more personalized, technology-enabled, timely care...all while in the comforts of home. It is time for this underperforming and antiquated sector to fade away. Selected Excerpt: “Thirty years ago, 90 percent of Medicaid dollars for long-term care. Now only 43 percent of Medicaid’s long-term care expenditures. It’s good news for consumers — but not so good for nursing homes.”       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post about the issue of healthcare being tied to employment in the United States, using the hashtags #healthcare and #paytolive. Make sure
output: Since When Do We Play ‘Quid Pro Quo’ with Basic Healthcare? No job? No Health Care. Sorry. Our U.S. Administration does not care if you are an American. Can’t pay? Can’t work? No Health Care for you. Your screwed. Bummer for you.  “Community engagement requirements (meaning—you have a job and  you are working) are not some subversive attempt to just kick people off of Medicaid," Seema Verma, head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services...” and yet 4,300 people were denied their medical coverage in Arkansas alone in one month—because of this rule. So I would submit a counter-point: “Uh...apparently it is.” Arkansas became the first state, in Medicaid's 53-year history, to strip coverage from beneficiaries for not meeting work requirements.  And next up is Indiana and New Hampshire (What happened to the State’s motto of ‘Live Free or Die?’ Maybe the revised state motto should be “Forced to Work or Die from Lack Of Health Care.) If you don’t feel a chill down your spine then you don’t grasp the far reaching nature of this governmental over-reach.  What’s next? Gotta prove you don’t have a pre-existing condition or that you don’t over eat? Yikes.  #healthcare   #paytolive       …see more

instruction: Create a post on the confusion surrounding the benefits of certain foods and supplements for health purposes.
output: Oops Wrong Conclusion: This is Why Its Hard to Advance Medicine and Public Health  Remember when “low-fat and high-carb” diets were all the rage, only to be proved (years later), to lead to weight gain, diabetes and heat disease—in part because of all the sugar added to processed foods? Or remember the buzz that oatmeal will stave-off heart disease? (Or eating only meat will not cause heart disease?!!)  And I can’t keep up—is coffee good or bad for us?? Well now we can add the lowly and pure aspirin to the list of things that don’t actually help stave-off heart disease (assuming you are just fine). With so much hyping by the food industry, academic research centers and wanna-be food celebrities pushing ‘nutrition’ and wellness, it is almost impossible to figure out what’s actually ‘good for you’ (and I mean from a longitudinal, epidemiological, medical-evidentiary manner...). Selected Excerpt: “The message for the public is that healthy older people should not begin taking aspirin. “If you don’t need it, don’t start it,” Dr. McNeil said.”       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about the issue of corruption in healthcare with specific examples of how big pharma and device manufacturers influence doctors and hospitals.
output: Trust. What does that word even mean anymore? Rules. Doesn’t anyone respect them anymore? If you can’t trust Sloan Kettering Cancer Institute to uphold the absolute highest ethical standards in cancer treatment, then what’s a clinician to do? When your “star doctor” lies about taking money from drug companies and breaks the rules regarding disclosure, and you pay him $1.5M a year to be your “face” of cancer care, then what’s that say about the Hospital? Believe me or not, but Healthcare—all the way to its core of using science and evidence in the medical treatment of patient guidelines—is corrupted by big pharma, device manufacturers and for-profit incentives to physicians (and hospitals). It breaks my clinical heart every time I read a story like this. Selected Excerpt: “...One of the world’s top breast cancer doctors failed to disclose millions of dollars in payments from drug and health care companies in recent years, omitting his financial ties from dozens of research articles in prestigious publications... ...He put a positive spin on the results of two Roche-sponsored clinical trials that many others considered disappointments, without disclosing his relationship to the company. Since 2014, he has received more than $3 million from Roche in consulting fees...”       …see more

Wehrum worked for the better part of a decade to weaken air pollution rules by fighting the Environmental Protection Agency in court on behalf of chemical manufacturers, refineries, oil drillers and coal-burning power plants. It’s when a drug is prescribed for other reasons than what it’s ‘officially’ made for.  “Off-label" means the medication is being used in a manner not specified in the FDA's approved packaging label, or insert. Every prescription drug marketed in the U.S. carries an individual, FDA-approved label. Selected Excerpts: The F.D.A. had data showing that so-called off-label prescribing was widespread. But officials did little to intervene... ...The F.D.A. established a distribution oversight program in 2011 to curb inappropriate use of the dangerous medications, but entrusted enforcement to a group of pharmaceutical companies that make and sell the drugs.. ...pharmaceutical companies “actively subverting” the oversight and safety process... ...the pharmaceutical company pleaded guilty and paid more than $600 million in fines related to misleading marketing... ..drug companies have faced legal action for falsely advertising medications and have  paid over $400 million in fines... “It is not open for debate that the risk of these drugs among patients  is unacceptably high. instruction: Hey, can you help me write a post similar to the one shared by [Author's Name] about the love for bread and how it's not justifiable to
output: Vindicated! Paleo...Shmaleo. Here’s to Bread! For years I’ve expressed my utter disregard for those friends of mine who claim they believe in the ‘paleo diet’ as an actual (historically accurate) food diet.  I’ve always said it’s a fad diet and that people who choose to be on this diet should just admit to it. And like all fads, it’s made-up to promote some sort of mindset or ‘evolved’ eating approach. Which is why a friend of mine (who has no allergies or sensitivity to any food products) won’t eat any kind of bread, grain, legumes, dairy, sugar or any number of other things. (Meanwhile coconut and cow are fine...) I’ve tried explaining to this friend that none of the foods she is eating today were even around 10,000 years ago and not to mention that the average lifespan back then was 45, so that I’m not really sure why we are eager to reproduce that diet. Anyway, as a lover of bread, I was tickled pink to read this article about how bread is in fact ‘paleo.’  Does that mean all those paleo books need to be re-written??? Selected Excerpt: “As a final note, this study reminds us, yet again, that the so-called Paleo Diet isn’t an actual thing, or at the very least, not a coherent, unified diet that existed across multiple populations of paleolithic peoples.”       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about how technology can help address the issue of medical errors. Include specific examples of technological solutions that have been successful in reducing medical errors and explain how
output: Being Human Hurts Patients. Being tired causes errors...it’s true whether you are a truck driver or a doctor. Medical errors are things like getting the wrong medication, being prescribed the wrong test, being diagnosed with the wrong problem. And it’s a huge problem as it is the 3rd leading cause of death. Medical errors happen for many, many reasons including doctors and nurses being tired, distracted, forgetful or simply out-of-date with best practices.  Only one of the  issues with medical errors is burn out. Lets face it, the bigger problem is that people are faulty instruments when it comes to high reliability, consistency and memory. That’s why I’m hopeful about technology-assisting advancements such as ‘smart’ (meaning automated) order sets, Smart radiological readings for x-rays, and ‘early warning’ technologies that diagnose medical conditions before they’ve advanced, just to name a few. The time is coming when the scope of what doctors do is narrower and more augmented by advanced capabilities. We should embrace this because honestly, right now, Healthcare is a very dangerous place for patients. Selected Excerpt: “There is growing evidence that physician burnout may be responsible for up to 200,000 deaths in US hospitals every year.”       …see more

instruction: User: Can you generate a post about a recent event that highlights the commonalities among people despite cultural differences?
output: I Am Not Different Than You Who doesn’t know about the boys who were trapped in the cave? It’s a funny thing—this is a story that opened the Evening News shows, and has been part of Americans daily talk news over the last two weeks. We’ve cheered for them, prayed for them, rooted for them. We gravitate towards stories that are suspenseful and hopeful—in our collective hearts we want everyone to ‘win,’ especially when it comes to the underdog, like these young boys appeared to be. (Who wouldn’t be an underdog trapped in a cave, two miles from freedom?) During their battle for survival, we learned that those boys are like our young ones: Sweet, resilient and hopeful. It reminds us that the human spirit to love others and our capacity to care about each other is something we all have in common regardless of where we live, the country we call home or the color of our skin. It’s an essential reminder for our times. Selected Excerpt: “What we want to say: The kids say don't worry. We are all strong. When they come out they want to eat many things.  When they come out they want to go back home immediately. Teacher, don't give us lots of homework!"       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post explaining why consumers prefer lower prices for identical products.Instruction: How do consumers feel about paying lower prices for identical products? In your opinion, why
output: Which is better?  Paying $18.99 or $7.40 for an identical (in every way) medicine? If you had the choice of buying one banana and paying either $1.00 or $4.00, I’d guess you’d (definitely) decide to pay $1.00... especially when you know $4.00 is overpriced for that banana. We think:‘Why pay more for an identical ‘thing’ when choice is available?’ So it should come as no surprise that Amazon is selling medicines at a lower—and I’d argue a more rational—price...and guess what? Consumers are not silly—we buy the lower priced, identical item when options exist. This is not ‘rocket science...’ Want to be competitive? Provide easy value for consumers and we will become your best paying friends. Let this be a warning shot to conventional businesses: understand this new consumer market...or perish. Selected Excerpt: “84% of Walgreens’ and 72% of CVS’ house-brand drugs were more expensive than the (Amazon’s) Basic Care line (of pharmaceuticals).”       …see more

According to Modern Healthcare... Regardless of who ‘should’ own Healthcare (and trust me, it won’t be patients), the group that’s moving into the ‘top spot’ is Private Equity firms (PE). They are buying as much of Healthcare as possible ( doctor groups, hospitals, lab services...) Huh? Never heard of PE?  Private equity typically refers to investment funds organized as limited partnerships that are not publicly traded and whose investors are typically large institutional investors, or wealthy individuals. And you thought Healthcare was already complex (and impersonal) before... Selected Excerpt: “We have to decide whether the goal of a healthcare system is to increase profits, because private equity firms are selecting those parts of healthcare where they can see a profit because their goal is to make profit,” AMA President Dr. Barbara McAneny said. “The consolidation of various parts of the healthcare industry has been shown to increase prices and decrease choice, and if you’re lucky, quality stays about the same.”       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post with a message promoting self-love and acceptance.Instruction: Create a LinkedIn post using the style and theme of the given text material, sharing
output: Women-to-Women: Life (and Career) Advice. My mom recently passed and I found a card from her which, honestly, I don't recall receiving...but reading it again, I think it is full of wisdom. Here it is: If I were your age again, I'd spend a lot less time examining what's wrong about me, and a lot more time enjoying what's right about me. Because you know what? You're already perfect enough. So, live life on your own terms. Be who you are and love what you love. Reserve the right to be wrong. If things take an occasional turn you hadn't planned on, don't be tempted to call it a mistake. Just call it life and tuck the experience in your back pocket for safe keeping. Pretty soon you can take it out, share it with someone else, and call it wisdom. I'm not kidding. That's how it works. So, hey--enjoy the life you're in. Be as happy as you can. And feel how deeply and completely you are loved....       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post about the importance of addressing mental health as a public health issue, using statistics and personal experiences to emphasize the urgency.
output: It's Time To Look At Suicide Squarely In The Eye Suicide is all around us.  While all other causes of death are declining, suicide is rising. I bet you know someone who has had issues with serious depression, anxiety, schizophrenia or bipolar. Or has taken their own life. My first experience with it was in high school when my good friend started to tell me things like ‘Paul McCartney stole my music. He took my songs from the freezer.’ (She was a budding musician). And one day she came to my house and started saying things like this around my dad, who was a doctor. After she left, he said, ‘You know Julie, your friend has schizophrenia.’ I had no idea even what the word meant. Years later one of my family members took her own life and mental illness became real. Real, tragic and deeply personal. It is time to address this growing cause of death in our society. Speak Up. Speak Out. Selected Excerpt: Increasingly, suicide is being viewed not only as a mental health problem but a public health one. Nearly 45,000 suicides occurred in the United States in 2016 — more than twice the number of homicides — making it the 10th-leading cause of death. Among people ages 15 to 34, suicide is the second-leading cause of death.       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about how cultural change is needed for innovation, using examples from healthcare.
output: Culture Eats Consumerism for Lunch   While ‘Consumerism’ is all the range in healthcare, moving beyond the slogans to the real-world of strategy development and implementation—and measurement—is still in its infancy. Why? Even though many technologies are mature enough to demonstrate real value, getting people within organizations to change from their old ways is hard. The biggest challenges to innovation is not the technical aspect of intraoperability or, realizing a return on investment, but rather on the necessary adoption, implementation and change management that goes hand-in-glove with innovation.   I do a lot of change management so I consider myself to be an “Organizational Culturalist.” As an Organizational Culturalist, I function like a medical anthropologist helping  organizations develop and implement technology adoption roadmaps.   If ‘culture’ is the biggest barrier, then it’s time to think of culture like anthropologists rather than technologists.   Selected Excerpt:    "Everybody thinks the only way you can innovate is to have some technological advance," he said. "We're finding a lot of innovations can occur without the use of technology but with changing the team and changing the thinking."       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about how integrated healthcare addresses both physical and mental health needs, using statistics to support your argument and providing examples of successful integrated care programs. Your post should also
output: Health= Body + Mind... Not Just The Body. The Bio-Medical Model Of Healthcare focuses largely on the germ theory as the dominant diagnoses and treatment approach: Got an infection? We’ve got an antibiotic! Got a laceration? We’ve got sutures. All great stuff for the body. But the mind requires a different sort of medical model—one that includes enough resources (and humanity) to have time to evaluate, diagnosis and treat. We continue to separate out the Body from the Mind at our own, collective expense... instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the importance of continuous care in the healthcare industry.
output: Healthcare. It should be more like Vegas--Always Open--But It Is Not. Is healthcare 'always open?' You might think it is, but it is not. In fact, it operates much more like a banker's hours than you'd think...or want! Did you know that in the hospital, many services end at 5pm? Like the team that insert special IVs for patients that cannot tolerate regular IVs? Or that social services closes? Or that discharge planners leave at 5pm too?  And if you were ready to be discharged from the hospital on Friday but arrangements for your rehab center (whether physical rehab or behavioral health rehab) hadn't been finalized yet, then most likely you have to spend another two--or three--days in the hospital until arrangements can be made... Talk about a waste of money and, talk about the increased opportunities to 'catch something' like a hospital-acquired infection. Hospitals and healthcare organizations still operate on a model of 9am-5pm, yet patient care is a continuous experience, requiring an entirely different operating model. One that is Always Open.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post highlighting tips for starting and maintaining a fitness routine, focusing on the importance of mindset and developing a personal mantra.
output: Thinking of Starting--or Re-Starting Working Out?  It's Springtime and which means its time to think about bicycling, upcoming trips to our beautiful National Parks, summer picnics. Which means feeling physically fit, 'light' and well, happy. I've started, stopped and re-started working-out too many times to count over the 40 years I've been exercising. Here's what I've learned: 1. Re-Set To Zero: Know you will start, stop and need to re-start exercising many, many times. I think of this as 'resetting to zero.'  2. Get into the Work-Out Mindset: Be kind to yourself and set winning 'goals' at the beginning of your 'work-out season.'  3. Feel Successful Each Time You Work-Out: It’s about the process of ‘doing’ so applaud yourself for ‘doing’ rather than judging ‘how much or how little’ you did. 4. Figure Out ‘Why’ You Want To Exercise: This becomes important to staying fit. 5. Develop a Personal Matra: By coming up with a ‘saying’ that you can repeat to yourself when you are working-out, that helps a lot. When I used to train for marathons, I would repeat to myself ‘The Mind Gives Out Before The Body.’  This is a good, comprehensive article on tips, ideas, strategies to help everyone start—or continue along their healthcare journey.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about gun violence that focuses on the difference between high-velocity weapons and traditional handguns in terms of their impact on human health.
output: What trauma doctors and nurses know ...the issue is NOT guns, but rather it’s the type of gun that will kill you. Just like how all viruses do not pack the same “killing punch,” it’s the same for guns. Years ago I worked in an inner-city trauma center and saw gun shot victims every shift. And you know what? Most lived. But that was before there were many high velocity weapons used in the streets. Just like viruses differ in their ability to inflict morbidity so does the “strain” or type of gun. Selected Excerpt from The Atlantic: “Routine handgun injuries leave entry and exit wounds and linear tracks through the victim’s body that are roughly the size of the bullet. If the bullet does not directly hit something crucial like the heart or the aorta, and the victim does not bleed to death before being transported to our care at the trauma center, chances are that we can save him. The bullets fired by an AR-15 are different: They travel at a higher velocity and are far more lethal than routine bullets fired from a handgun. The damage they cause is a function of the energy they impart as they pass through the body. A typical AR-15 bullet leaves the barrel traveling almost three times faster than—and imparting more than three times the energy of—a typical 9mm bullet from a handgun.”       …see more

So I really am interested in knowing more...  I live here in Oakland and would like to suggest that you invite me to meet you at your office to discuss my experiences and views of Healthcare in 2018! I do hope you’ll take me up on my invitation to meet. And If we meet, I'll share a post of our meeting with my fellow LinkedIn Followers!!”       …see more

instruction: Can you summarize the concerns raised by healthcare experts about recent roll-backs in efforts to improve patient outcomes under the ACA? And can you provide some examples of these roll
output: Reducing patient quality of care: Why are we going back in time? Many of us don't have the time (or inclination) to follow every maneuver occurring regarding changes to the ACA. This article talks about a really important aspect of the ACA which is linking physician and hospital payment to quality measures--meaning payment models which rewards better care and outcomes for us, the patients...Rather than linking payment to doctors for simply doing things--regardless of quality or outcomes for us, the patient. As someone who specializes in organization safety and quality of care--and as a patient--these roll-backs concern me....as they should you as well. Selected Excerpt: “Clearly a great big foot has been put on the brake,” said Donald Crane, the chief executive of CAPG, a group of doctors and hospital administrators that, unlike many in the profession, has pushed to tie physician pay to quality measures rather than the old model of fee for service.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the topic of patient compliance in healthcare, exploring factors such as the role of communication between doctors and patients, potential cultural barriers, and strategies to address
output: Nudging patients to do things like taking medications does not work, as it turns out. So how do doctors and nurses partner with their patients to be more "compliant?" (Note: I do not care for this term since it is prerogative and connotes 'bad patient/good provider.') Why don't patients do 'what's in their best interest ?' Is it possible the down sides are not clear or are we humans only "wired" to deal with the "here and now..." come what may? Just as we are bad with dieting or exercise perhaps the same is true when it comes time to take our meds. Selected Excerpt: "A thorough review published in The New England Journal of Medicine about a decade ago estimated that up to two-thirds of medication-related hospital admissions in the United States were because of noncompliance, at a cost of about $100 billion a year. These included treatments for H.I.V., high blood pressure, mental health and childhood illnesses (it can be difficult to get children to take their medicine, too)."       …see more

instruction: Can you help me craft a post that raises awareness about the negative impacts of lack of healthcare coverage on individuals and society as a whole? Make sure to include statistics and personal stories
output: Do we care? Do we care that health insurance coverage is dropping ?  Anyone on LinkedIn going without insurance?   My guess is most people reading this have coverage and don't worry about falling off their bike, or a nail through the foot, or a fever in your child at night, or routine medical checkups, or cholesterol levels, or pneumonia or.... BECAUSE you've got insurance . But for those who go "bare," every one of those things I mentioned are fears you harbor or desires you can't fulfill --regular medical exam--get ready to pay $300-1,000.00 bucks. Sick child? Don't even think about it because you'll need to sell your house if they need hospitalization. Those of us with coverage should care for no other reason that WE pay the bills for all those who go without ... not to mention it's a decent and civil thing to provide our fellow Americans. Selected Excerpt : "Experts expect the cuts and confusion over whether the law is being repealed will further depress enrollment - which could cause the rate of people without insurance to rise further."       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the importance of improving access to healthcare in underprivileged communities as a means of reducing unnecessary emergency room visits.
output: For many years I worked in a high-volume, urban ED. I treated people--who became patients--for everything you could imagine: a fork stuck in an eyeball causing an ocular rupture, a nose bleed that put a person into volume shock because of how much blood was lost, abdominal pain that turned out to be an ectopic pregnancy, an achy leg which turned out to be a fractured femur...and on and on and on. Sure, I also saw people seek 'emergency care' for heartburn, lice, sexually transmitted diseases, skin lesions, mild sunburns and on and on and on..... But how on earth can we expect the 'lay public' to know when to seek emergency treatment and when not to?  Honestly--think about this..many people do not have primary care doctors so they come to the ED...many people do not want to wait weeks for an appointment to see a doctor so they come to the ED...many people don't know if they are truly sick or not truly sick...so they come to us. Until there is more access to care in communities where people live, then we will always have people coming to the ED--whether they should or not...and we need to cover the costs.       …see more

instruction: How can we overcome the resistance to healthcare reform caused by the focus on financial gain rather than patient care? What strategies can we implement to shift the mindset and prioritize healthcare as

output: Do not breath a sigh of relief if your hospital has The Joint Commission Seal of Approval...as many of us in healthcare know, this accreditation standard represents 'the floor (or basement)' of performance, not the ceiling . Want to really know if your hospital is safe? Ask the doctors and nurses--privately and "off the record"--and you might get the truth. One key question to ask them:'Would you go here for your surgery ?' Selected excerpt : "The Wall Street Journal dug into Joint Commission inspection reports from 2014 through 2016. In 2014, about 350 hospitals with Joint Commission accreditation were in violation of Medicare requirements that year, and about a third of those facilities went on to have additional violations in 2014, 2015 and 2016. About 80% of U.S. hospitals are accredited by the commission."       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post similar in style and tone to the one provided, advocating for the need for new entrants with innovative ideas to revolutionize the education sector. High
output: Here I am again cheerleading for an "Outsider" to come to Healthcare's aide!  I've been a consistent advocate for new entrants with bold ideas driven by creative, optimistic leaders, to provide CPR!  Like Apple and Amazon. My belief is that  "The Healthcare Institutional Mindset"  (including hospitals, nursing facilities and delivering systems) is one which is fundamentally risk-adverse, backwards-thinking and myopic.  Within these organizations you will not find "skunk works" or "innovation labs" or "stealthy teams" working on new approaches to patient care. In healthcare we are designed (and hire) for being slow, cautious and repetitious ... even if doing the same thing over and over leads to the same mediocre and disappointing results. Again I say "Apple, come find me! I'm just up the road and am here to help improve care delivery for patients !" Selected excerpt: "The iPhone, which turned 10 this summer, already aggregates some health data in apps. But most of that is patient-generated. If the company can add information from doctors offices and clinics—test results, visit summaries, medication lists—the iPhone could become an important healthcare tool in achieving interoperability, which has for so long frustrated the industry."       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post discussing the complexities of planning for the end of life and how technology and innovation are shaping this process. Include examples of current initiatives and resources,
output: I'm mixed about this piece: on one hand I say "Hat's Off" to anyone  or any formalized group of people trying to 'think about making dying better.'  For whatever the reasons, we do not like talking about The Dying Process....and yet we all go through some form of death--and die. On the other hand, we know not all death can be planned-having worked in a busy ER, I saw people die daily even though their plan for the day was to get to work, or drive to school, or go hang out with friends...what about this "death and dying process?" And, once you "package and brand"  (or should I say "re-brand") The Dying Process, how will you make sure all this new wisdom moves out of the fancy world of Silicon Vally and into  the hands of every day people? I wish you well AND I hope you routinely share--for free--all the tools and knowledge you are acquiring... because as you say, this affects us all and as such, any "solution " should be viewed as a public good.       …see more

instruction: The AI response:User: Hey, can you help me come up with a LinkedIn post that shares a similar theme as the one I just read? It's about how

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post in which you discuss the potential for disruption in healthcare delivery through innovative technologies such as telemedicine and wearable devices.
output: I hope Amazon does take over healthcare... personally, I like on-time delivery and friendly customer service and being asked whether I was satisfied with the service I received. And sure, I know (I know!), healthcare is not like package delivery. But let's face it-many aspects of care delivery is about delivering the correct good or service to the right person/patient, at the right time. It is also about caring and doing the right thing. And while individual healthcare providers do the right thing all the time, the collective effort of the health care enterprise routinely fails  to deliver the right service at the right time to the right person in a customer-service orientation . So Hats Off to Amazon and any other "big dog" who wants to completely re-do a broken industry . And Amazon--if you are reading this, please call me because I want to help realize a vision of customer -oriented, high value health care!       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post, similar in style and theme to the one shared by Amy, highlighting the lack of compassion in healthcare during the pandemic crisis. Use real-life
output: Thanks Amy for sharing this short example about how (seemingly ) petty healthcare has become.  It seems clear from your post that your three year old son has a medical condition requiring him to learn anew how to safely swallow food... basic human need--to safely eat and drink without concern of choking ... and yet the Occupational Therapy services and "associated tools (e.g., food)" were not included as a covered benefit with your insurance.  Let me ask--how was your 3 year old son supposed to get better without the help of  trained health care professionals ? What bothers me in so many of these healthcare posts is an undying sense of pettiness, and disregard for people's medical problems... wether that disregard is coming from insurance providers or the public.  Healthcare should be held above  all other industries to be caring, loving and selfless. Which I know we all want to experience when our time comes to deal with doctors , nurses and insurers.       …see more

Too often when you call doctors /nurses with a problem, they offer to see you in their office or tell you to go to the ER... An imaginative scenario about a critical care physician at a medium-sized urban hospital who has to implement an A.I. coming from a local start-up that claims to automatically interpret chest X-rays.    While treating breast cancer, physicians use a quick, inexpensive tumor-tissue stain test to diagnose the illness and a slower, more costly one to determine treatment. A new study just presented a neural network that could help. The stain in the test for treatment highlights a key visual clue to the choice of therapy that’s otherwise invisible to human pathologists. Researchers built it to detect that clue in the diagnostic test.    The question of who should get access to COVID-19 vaccines first has varied from state to state in the US too, with some governments prioritizing those with high-risk conditions and others lowering the age of eligibility. instruction: Create a LinkedIn post promoting a new study on artificial intelligence in healthcare using the hashtags #aihealthcare and #innovation.
output: Are you familiar with the Gary rule? As many are still mixing up ‘health IT’ and ‘digital health’, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to help clear up this misconception.  Here’s how it goes: If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  #study   #tmfi   #research   #themedicalfuturistinstitute   #garyrule   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology       …see more

instruction: Can you summarize the findings of the recent study by Mount Sinai researchers on how Apple Watches can help detect new cases of COVID-19? And can you
output: Mount Sinai researchers just released a study indicating that consumer wearable devices can help flag new cases of COVID-19 prior to molecular diagnosis.  They analyzed Mount Sinai Health System workers with an Apple Watch and a custom study app and found significant differences in a heart rate variability (HRV) metric during the seven days before a PCR COVID-19 diagnosis and the seven days after. While it could also indicate that other heart rate trackers are capable of the same feat, the study only had 297 participants so we cannot draw that conclusion yet. Yet it shows promise how wearable digital health devices could contribute to the early diagnosis of COVID. #applewatch   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy       …see more

instruction: User: Hey, could you help me come up with a social media post about events in the new normal? The style should be similar to this one, with the same themes and tone.
output: I've done 50 keynotes in the last 6 months so I’m reflecting a bit on what keynotes will be like in the new “never normal”. My take so far: Virtual keynotes don’t work at large expos with 1,000s of people and exhibitors. At such events, we’d like to immerse ourselves in a different world. We’d like to see and experience the venue, thus bringing such events to a single screen (with break-out rooms or not) is a complete waste. Whereas it’s not worth organizing events in the physical space with 150 attendees or less. I believe these won’t be coming back and I’d strongly agree there’s no need.  I can’t wait to hop on a plane for large-scale events all over the world, but I’ll be happy to continue giving smaller keynotes from the comfort and professionality of my new studio: it’s cozier, it creates a more honest environment and I even get better questions! instruction: Can you write a social media post like the one you just showed me about 3D-printed medical equipment being cheaper than manufactured ones?
output: *Is Printing Out Medical Equipment Cheaper Than Manufacturing?* Revolutionary technologies bring a healthier future. In my book, “My Health Upgraded”, I’m sharing the most exciting questions (and providing answers) about the future of medicine. In the upcoming month, I’ll share with you one question from my book each week and provide a short (but sweet) answer. Question 4: Is Printing Out Medical Equipment Cheaper Than Manufacturing?  In short: YES. And not only that, it’s much more customizable. 3D printing works by additive manufacturing, which means that a digital model is created of the object we want to print out, and the machine adds each layer one at a time. That way, a personalized, 3D printed cast could get ready in 2 minutes and would cost around $50.  Wealthy companies will turn to 3D printing because of its potential for total customization. Companies in poorer regions will turn to it because it makes prototypes inexpensively.  Grab your paperback to become more conscious about your health as a patient from the future! http://amzn.to/1LRAp3t #myhealthupgraded   #3dprinting   #3dprinter   #3dprinted   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #technology       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post about the future of digital health records in the context of end-of-life care, focusing on emerging technologies and potential implications for patient privacy and healthcare providers

instruction: Write a post on LinkedIn about why it's crucial to prioritize actual outcomes over tracking metrics, and provide specific examples of which metrics should be minimized in favor of
output: Generally speaking. The metrics we can measure most easily-  are the ones that matter the least. The metrics we can change the fastest - are the ones that matter the least. The metrics we can measure most precisely - are the ones that matter the least. The metrics that we can attribute change to the most easily - are the ones that matter least. So by all means track things like Social Sentiment, Click Through Rates, but don't ever think they have any real importance except as a very vague disconnected proxy for the brutal things that matter like impact on sales, brand awareness, or net promoter score that are not found easily.       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post that discusses the impact of cancel culture on brand monitoring and reputation management, while also exploring the idea that 'everything is marketing.' Make sure to include
output: Despite the impact of cancel-culture, within a time of frantic brand monitoring and reputation management... I'm constantly reminded of a quote from Andy Warhol in 1980:  "Don't pay any attention to what they write about you. Just measure it in inches.” (Newspaper inches.)  Mark Ritson  is out with a new piece about the real impact of overly-crafted brand image: "Over the past decade marketers have come to learn that, rather than just the gateway, coming to mind and being present in the consumer’s consciousness during decision-making is most of the house and the back garden too...  The superiority of salience reflects a growing awareness that, in the age of Trump, what people think of you is far less important than the more brutal objective of getting people to think about you." I agree with that. And, this: "We overthought things and made the cardinal error of assuming brands were as big for consumers as they were for us marketers... We need to calm down. We need to take more risks." Someone once said this, maybe I dreamt it: Everything is marketing, but  #marketing  isn't everything.  (Mark's post in comments  #feedthealgorithm )       …see more

instruction: Write a social media post similar to the one shared by my LinkedIn connection about the role of business leaders during recent political unrest, focusing on concrete actions that can be taken
output: What is the role of business leaders after yesterday's riots disrupting the transfer of political power in Washington?  Cold hard cash speaks volumes: “Respect for the rule of law underlies our market economy. Business leaders need to stand up on these issues because in the end they are business issues, not just politics as usual. Just coming out with another public letter isn’t going to do much. Money is the key way.”  - Thomas Glocer, former CEO  Thompson Reuters , director at  Merck  and  Morgan Stanley  in WSJ (linked below). i.e. withholding political donations or investments in certain states.  One of the country's largest lobbying groups, the National Association of Manufacturers even went so far as to encourage the use of the 25th Amendment. (NYTimes, linked below.)  Most were quick to denounce the violence via statements like Sundar Pichai of  Alphabet Inc. : "The lawlessness and violence occurring on Capitol Hill today is the antithesis of democracy and we strongly condemn it." Alphabet-owned YouTube, despite deleting a video from the president yesterday, still radicalizes many on the far-right with content full of conspiracy theories, misogyny, and racism. (NYTimes, linked below.) I don't have a blueprint for CEOs, but actions still matter more than words.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post discussing the importance of critical thinking and advocacy in the marketing industry, and how it can lead to positive change while also acknowledging the potential negative impacts of
output: Tell exceptional truths - what needs to be said in order to make things right. Speak up. Advocate. And if you create friction in that process, keep going -  creating discomfort is the first step towards change.   My convo with  Derek J. Horn  on his new podcast gets into this and more. "I have a ton of respect for our industry, but I think it needs a balance of criticism and critique of activism and continually questioning if what we're doing is the right thing for everybody affected by what we do.  And what we do as marketers is the, I say the world's most powerful industry. And so we really need to keep it in check sometimes.  I've been writing about some of the illusions of progress that we say that we make in  #marketing  and some of the ugly truths behind that, but I think that's important to just keep moving the industry forward." instruction: User Instruction: Can you help me craft a LinkedIn post similar to the one shared by [user's name] about the importance of culture versus technology in digital transformations?
output: Which matters more, the right culture, or the right tech? I spoke to  Richard George  about his  #adobeexperiencemakerawards  win at  Refinitiv , and our convo (link in comments) made me wonder.  Without a doubt, tech is at the core of their award-winning digital ecosystem.  But, it simply isn't the hero of this story.  It’s the critical infrastructure that enables innovation.  But, what brought that innovation to life, what sustains it, and what facilitated such a remarkable transformation is this organization’s relentless focus on culture. Quoting Richard from our interview: “That was something we were very purposeful about from the get-go. We made sure that people were aligned around a shared purpose, and that they trusted each other to see that vision through.” Check out the link in the comments for key elements of this winning culture, and hear from Richard directly in our full conversation. Joan Donovan suggests in  MIT Technology Review  that this tactic, used to illustrate dangers of secondhand smoke, may help combat misinformation on sites like  #Facebook : "a broad public campaign to address the dangers of secondhand smoke is what finally broke the industry's heavy reliance on the myth of smoking as a personal freedom.  It wasn’t enough to suggest that smoking causes lung disease and cancer, because those were personal ailments—an individual’s choice. But secondhand smoke? That showed how those individual choices could harm other people... ...To achieve policy change, researchers and advocates had to demonstrate that the cost of doing nothing was quantifiable in lost productivity, sick time, educational programs, supplementary insurance, and even hard infrastructure expenses such as ventilation and alarm systems.  If these externalities hadn’t been acknowledged, perhaps we’d still be coughing in smoke-filled workplaces, planes, and restaurants.  And, like secondhand smoke,  #misinformation  damages the quality of public life." Link in comments- a must read.       …see more

Whereas each additional consensus voice doesn’t make much impact, a single dissenting voice has the power to bring the entire argument down.  10 people all saying the same thing is far less interesting than the 1 person that has a reasonable, opposing view."       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post promoting a webinar about social responsibility in marketing. Please ensure that it includes a brief introduction explaining why social responsibility is essential in today's business landscape
output: Join me on 10/27 for "The New Rules of Marketing in an Age of Social Change" at Connect to Convert.  I'll be joined by  Julie Perino , Head of Global Customer Marketing at  Adobe . 2020 has signaled a strange new normal, one in which consumers increasingly look to align with brands on values that extend well beyond what our products and services do. It has caught many marketing teams unprepared for this collision between social movements and marketing. Amid the chaos, there is an opportunity for all brands to earn trust, stay relevant, and create loyalty and growth. It requires us to take meaningful actions that help both our organizations and the communities and movements now driving global narratives. If this is the new normal, we need new rules of engagement. In this interactive session with unapologetic marketing truth-teller Katie Martell and Julie Perino of Adobe, you will hear: - The difference between meaningful support and pandering  - The seven risks of performative brand allyship - How to navigate an age of accountability, cancel culture and employee activism Hope we'll see you there - link to register is in the comments.       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post with a focus on B2B marketing strategies that highlights the importance of building trust in the industry and provides practical tips for achieving it.
output: We don’t do business with people (or companies) we do not trust. In many industries, being the most trusted can actually deliver a competitive advantage and a brand differentiator. In a world of mistrust, the brand that earns the most trust wins: More than two-thirds (68%) of U.S. adults say that trust in a brand has a great deal of influence when making a large purchase decision. Trusted companies are found to have stronger buyers and advocates. From the Harvard Business Review: Businesses that build trust among their customers are rewarded with greater loyalty and higher sales. And negotiators who build trust with each other are more likely to find value-creating deals. The bad news? Marketers are facing a massive decline in trust — and it threatens to undermine brands' ability to drive sustained growth. Read how to build trust in  #B2B   #Marketing  in my 100% free book, made available through  TriComB2B .  https://lnkd.in/dfg2Bcq       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post in the style of the given one about how Facebook has emulated tactics used by the pharmaceutical industry in promoting addiction to prescription drugs. Provide
output: 3 ways  #Facebook  pulled from Big Tobacco's addictive playbook: 1. Like adding sugar and menthol to cigarettes, Facebook added status updates, photo tagging, and likes, making status and reputation primary. 2. Big Tobacco’s bronchodilators (allowing cigarette smoke to cover more surface area of the lungs) is like Facebook allowing misinformation, conspiracy theories, and fake news to flourish. 3. Tobacco companies added ammonia to cigarettes to increase the speed of nicotine to the brain, like Facebook’s extreme, incendiary content— shocking images, graphic videos, and headlines that incite outrage— sowing tribalism and division.   Tim Kendall, Facebook's first Director of Monetization testified before the House Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee this week claiming to have intentionally made the product as addictive as cigarettes.  "These algorithms have brought out the worst in us. They’ve literally rewired our brains so that we’re detached from reality and immersed in tribalism. This is not by accident. It’s an algorithmically optimized playbook to maximize user attention -- and profits." Link to his full comments below.       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about how to overcome procrastination using proven techniques from reputable sources.
output: Anxiety shows up in our thinking patterns around work: - Catastrophizing: Imagining the worst possible outcome. “I will get fired if the presentation has any glitches.” - Mind reading: Imagining what others are thinking. “I know he doesn’t like working with me because he thinks I’m dumb.” - Fortune telling: Imagining what the future holds, but without data. “They will all hate me in the new group because I’m the only one who isn’t a physicist.” - Black-and-white thinking: Considering only two possible outcomes. “I’ll either hit a home run or get fired.” - Overgeneralizing: Painting all situations with a generalized outcome. “I presented to the CEO last year, and it didn’t go well. I never get things right or always fail when it comes to executive audiences.” This great HBR article offers strategies for overcoming these via  Sabina Nawaz . https://lnkd.in/d2_MN-D       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post that delves into how businesses can contribute to addressing issues related to Black Lives Matter and systemic racism, emphasizing the importance of increasing economic

And so really in age of  #BlackLivesMatter , no business is immune to this topic because every business has a role in the  #systemicracism  that the movement seeks to address.  So I hope anyone listening, who thinks 'we're not part of the problem, and therefore we're not part of the solution.' I hope you take a moment to pause and really question that assumption because I do think this is a chance for all businesses to say, 'we actually have a role to play in the, in the solution here. We actually have a role to play in increasing economic prosperity for all. And to be honest about it.'  And that's why you're seeing so many brands struggle to figure out what to do next. This is a new question. It's an age of accountability in sunlight, forcing brands to be quite honest about the dire state of  #diversity - look at the  #tech  industry and look at the  #investment  community.  People say the word reckoning. It is truly feeling to me like it is a reckoning. instruction: Can you write a post about systemic inequality that highlights the struggles working moms face due to race and gender? Use statistics and real-life examples to illustrate your points. Make
output: Today is Mom’s Equal Pay Day (June 4) "marking the 156 extra days moms have to work to make what dads made last year." https://lnkd.in/ebZcwgr "Working moms face inherent bias — an assumption that they are less committed to their jobs once they have children — and this is further compounded when faced with racial bias. Working moms also face a lack of institutional policies and practices like flex time, paid family leave and affordable childcare — and women of color are more likely to work in low-paying industries with fewer of these benefits (a lack of paid family leave is particularly concerning for black moms given that they face higher rates of complications from pregnancy). And finally, let’s not forget that caregiving disproportionately falls to mothers, affecting their careers and their earning potential. Women of color are also more likely to say that childcare is difficult to find, with nearly 40% of black women citing cost as a factor. But in looking at the mother’s pay gap through this lens, we still need to be honest with ourselves – as this moment demands – and recognize that we have not yet scratched the surface of the larger frame of institutionalized racism in American society."       …see more

instruction: Hey, can you help me come up with a LinkedIn post about supporting the LGTBQ community during Pride Month? It should include specific actions or strategies for companies
output: As we approach pride month (June), this news stings. Aimee Stephens passed today. She was fired from her job when she told her boss she was transgender. The Supreme Court is due to rule on her case this week.  One of her last acts was to write a public letter to America’s employers urging them to: 1. Implement clear non-discrimination policies 2. Ensure equitable bathroom usage  3. Cover transition-related medical care  4. Educate leaders and respect those outside of the gender binary and those who are transitioning. (Including something as basic as eye contact.)  "You have the ability to create and expand spaces where we belong – both at work and in our communities: When LGBTQ people are dehumanized, when our civil rights and our well-being are threatened by anti-LGBTQ legislation, companies have the power to blunt these attacks." This is what it means to support the LGBTQ community next month, not just rainbow-covered social media activations. RIP Aimee. Letter via  Out & Equal (TW for mention of suicidal thoughts within the letter.) https://lnkd.in/ekHazHF #pride2020   #LGTBQ   #equality       …see more

instruction: User: Hey, can you help me write a post similar to this one about B2B marketing and data services in the martech space? I want to discuss how to overcome the challenge
output: Our sales team called themselves "data slingers."  10 years ago I was hired by  Mark J. Feldman  to grow a data services brand in a then-emerging  #B2B   #martech  space.  There were only ~100 tools on the map as  #demandgen  teams bought our prospect lists to fuel email/call blitzes.  Some did it well, others simply spammed the living daylights out of those CSV files. Today, not much has changed, and yet, everything is different. Over a decade later, even with 10x more tools, the task of acquiring contacts still threatens to derail even the best laid plans - but this time, it's  #ABM  at risk.  Why can't teams find the right contacts for accounts? Why don't more demand gen pros think in an account-based way, like Sales? Are we ever going to shake our MQL-based ethos? Mark is now the head of revenue operations at Localytics, and I've asked him back for a reunion with me live this Friday at 1:00pm ET for a conversation about how things have changed in 10 years, and today, how to solve this new (but old) ABM data problem.  Live here on LinkedIn we'll dig into: - The messy yet critical task of choosing target accounts, and why less is more - How to find, and use, contact records appropriately  - The truth about working with data slingers like us See you there?       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post about a recent philanthropic effort from a well-known brand in your industry, highlighting the specific cause or community being supported, any unique aspects of
output: A new line of action figures and toys was launched by Mattel under the hashtag  #ThankYouHeroes . "The 16 action figures ($20 each) of doctors, nurses, EMTs and delivery drivers come in various genders and skin colors."  The net proceeds ($15) from each sale will go to  #FirstRespondersFirst .  I thought at first -- yikes. Is this merely capitalizing on the hero narrative we see around first responders in lieu of what they need (PPE!)  In a sense, yes.   Is this helping? Maybe it helps parents help their children navigate the dynamics of the pandemic.  Can the company do more? They are:  "These new Fisher-Price toys are part of what Mattel calls its new "Play It Forward" toy initiative to support communities in times of need. Mattel also has donated cloth masks to medical personnel and is now producing 500,000 face shields to donate."  It ultimately begs the question: what is the role of a toy company in a pandemic?  How do we delineate between pandering to consumers' desire to thank first responders, and meaningful support?  Those answers are unclear to me - it seems to have "checked all the boxes" (even around  #diversity , hey) but leaves a strange taste.  What do you think? Thanks to  Alicia Esposito  for finding!  Link in comments       …see more

output: Great advice for  #B2B   #marketing  from  Lee Odden "While there will be a period of adjustment, these changes do not mean the work stops. It doesn’t mean companies don’t need information, solutions, support, products and services. The evolving environment we find ourselves in presents new challenges and opportunities to be even more relevant and useful for clients. While some companies may be distracted or paused in some of their efforts to find solutions, that only means marketing needs to do a better job of providing best answer content in formats that are relevant in the new environment: virtual events, video conferencing, podcasts, webinars, interactive content, recorded video, live streaming and other forms of online engagement. Virtual reality or direct mail are considerations as well. During this time of transition, it’s also important that marketers review their planned advertising, social and marketing messages to be appropriate to what customers are dealing with right now. Publishing marketing messages as if everything is normal will not resonate or be useful."       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post using the hashtags #internationalwomensday, #femvertising, and #iwd2020 to discuss the importance of
output: As we celebrate  #InternationalWomensDay , it's time for  #femvertising  (feminist advertising.) A reminder as you experience, celebrate, or share these ads: Women don’t need to be pandered to.  Are we really fooled by faux-feminist marketing? For some women, yes. We're so used to the objectification of women in advertising (see all of  Jean Kilbourne 's work) that anything that resembles girl-power is celebrated. But I believe we need to raise our standards. The struggle of pay inequality, workplace sexual harassment and other forms of gender discrimination is not just another trend to exploit in order to gain eyeballs and trust. In a perfect world, brands and their agencies would stop trying to make a buck on the backs of those who have worked to create real change.  As much as I appreciate the intention, at the end of the day most companies deploying  #IWD  campaigns are simply bandwagoning with the global women's rights movement.  They exploit a narrative to achieve a common goal: Sell more product. Differentiate. Earn trust.  Most are not even held to the most basic standards of practicing what they preach internally, or within their industry. As we celebrate  #IWD2020  let's not lose sight of a very simple truth - Women are not a commodity. Shop and share consciously.       …see more

instruction: Create a social media post for International Women's Day, highlighting specific actions taken by brands to support women all year round. Use the hashtags #iwd2
output: Everyone knows this famous advice from  Simon Sinek 's 2009 TED talk:  "People don't buy what you do; they buy why you do it."  We can all quote it. We've all read (or pretended to) Start With Why.  But the second part of this quote is more important than the first: “People don't buy what you do; they buy why you do it. And what you do simply proves what you believe." What you do PROVES what you believe. Actions are louder than words.  As we near  #InternationalWomensDay , and as I continue to work on this passion project documentary and book about the rise of lip service, pandering, and virtue-signaling by brands, I'm looking for real action in addition to words.  How are brands supporting women 365 days a year, outside of Women's History Month? And, DESPITE it being Women's History Month?  Thank you in advance to everyone who's been sending me the campaigns that are catching their attention this year - some that are pandering, some that are fantastic.  International Women's Day is March 8th. Here come the campaigns! Send me yours:  katie@katie-martell.com   #iwd2020   #IWD20   #eachforequal       …see more

output: 3 things I learned in my livestream this week with  Zoë Randolph  +  Toby Murdock : 1.  #Digitalmarketing , by nature, creates content chaos if marketers are not diligent about operations. 2. instruction: For instance, Create a post about the impact of micro-influencers on marketing campaigns using the theme #trendwatcher. Make sure to include examples of successful collaborations and tips
output: What are your thoughts on  #kidfluencers ?  E.g. a 7 year old earning $22M on YouTube reviewing toys and launching a line of toys with Walmart, 3 year old twins with 4M Instagram followers levying their fame to a clothing line at Target, a 7 year old promoting dancewear to nearly 5M followers. Traackr  gave me the chance to explore this issue in a new series  #TrendLightly .  In it, I explore the gray area between entrepreneurship and exploitation, in which parents and talent agents drive hundreds of thousands, if not millions of dollars in revenue from children.  Child actors have existed since the days of Charlie Chaplin discovering Jackie Coogan (which, subsequently led to protective measures like the Coogan Law preventing parents from entirely hoarding their actor kids’ earnings).  They are branded as influencers, actors, and celebrities with the help of entrepreneurial, digitally-savvy parents and agents.  Kids are not always unwilling participants. But, do they understand the implications?  Feat. insights from  Katelyn Holbrook . Link in comments! What are your thoughts?  #influencermarketing   #socialmedia       …see more

instruction: Write a LinkedIn post on personal branding that emphasizes the importance of authenticity, consistency, and clearly communicating your unique value proposition. Include practical tips for craft
output: I was asked my top five tips on  #personalbranding : 1. Brands matter.  We live in a world of options and commoditization. Whether you’re an individual or a corporation, your brand is what distinguishes you from all other lookalike options, and defines your place in the world.  2. A brand is a promise.  Branding goes deeper than colors, font, logos, or a headshot. It’s a promise you make to the world; this is the kind of experience you will have with me.  Live up to that promise, consistently. 3. Perception is reality.  Marketing, at its core, is about changing perception. Building a personal brand is about being thoughtful about the perception the world has about you.  Use it to get you where you want to go, not to satisfy your ego. Clarify your end-game. 4. Ask for three words. If you’re stuck defining yourself in a pithy way (it’s not easy) ask friends and colleagues to describe you in three words.  Look for patterns.  5. Be yourself. Don’t try to be the person you think you should be. Have confidence in what you bring to the table. Your best brand strengths come from what differentiates you.  If you're in Boston, join us Thurs night at Shopify for a panel event and workshop on this topic aimed at entrepreneurs! (Link in comments.)       …see more

instruction: Create a LinkedIn post about the importance of being an effective moderator in panels, sharing tips and techniques for keeping discussions engaging and productive, and including examples or personal experiences to illustr
output: Honestly: I truly enjoy moderating panels! A good moderator makes a world of difference - we've all experienced the opposite. Done right, the conversation is wildly valuable for audiences / event organizers.  I found this article helpful for anyone who's been asked to moderate, especially when you're faced with the dreaded situation of a long-winded panelist: "If the event organizers had wanted that person to monologue, they would have given them a keynote. Instead, they put them on a panel in order to get their perspective as part of a group conversation, and you’ve been chosen to uphold that intention. If you’re wondering whether someone is droning on too long, the audience probably thinks they are. It’s crucial to remember that the audience will be rooting for you to stop the soliloquy. I’ve discovered one way to help the verbose panelist save face: cut them off with a positive statement. You can capture their attention by simultaneously making a hand gesture and breaking in verbally, and say something like, “That’s a great point, Joe, and I’d love to hear how Preeti would respond to that.”  https://lnkd.in/e_347gM       …see more
